StandardsSubscriptions.documentation: The details of the standards subscriptions that were enabled.

AutomationRulesArns.documentation: A list of rule ARNs to get details for.

Rules.documentation: A list of rule details for the provided rule ARNs.

UnprocessedAutomationRules.documentation: A list of objects containing RuleArn, ErrorCode, and ErrorMessage. This parameter tells you which automation rules the request didn't retrieve and why.

ConfigurationPolicyAssociationIdentifier.documentation: Specifies one or more target account IDs, organizational unit (OU) IDs, or the root ID to retrieve associations for.

ConfigurationPolicyAssociations.documentation: Describes associations for the target accounts, OUs, or the root.

UnprocessedConfigurationPolicyAssociatio.documentation: An array of configuration policy associations, one for each configuration policy association identifier, that was specified in the request but couldn’t be processed due to an error.

SecurityControlIds.documentation: A list of security controls (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters). The security control ID or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is the same across standards.

SecurityControls.documentation: An array that returns the identifier, Amazon Resource Name (ARN), and other details about a security control. The same information is returned whether the request includes SecurityControlId or SecurityControlArn.

UnprocessedIds.documentation: A security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) for which details cannot be returned.

StandardsControlAssociationIds.documentation: An array with one or more objects that includes a security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) and the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a standard. This field is used to query the enablement status of a control in a specified standard. The security control ID or ARN is the same across standards.

StandardsControlAssociationDetails.documentation: Provides the enablement status of a security control in a specified standard and other details for the control in relation to the specified standard.

UnprocessedAssociations.documentation: A security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) whose enablement status in a specified standard cannot be returned.

Findings.documentation: A list of findings to import. To successfully import a finding, it must follow the Amazon Web Services Security Finding Format. Maximum of 100 findings per request.

FailedCount.documentation: The number of findings that failed to import.

SuccessCount.documentation: The number of findings that were successfully imported.

FailedFindings.documentation: The list of findings that failed to import.

UpdateAutomationRulesRequestItems.documentation: An array of ARNs for the rules that are to be updated. Optionally, you can also include RuleStatus and RuleOrder.

ProcessedAutomationRules.documentation: A list of properly processed rule ARNs.

UnprocessedAutomationRules.documentation: A list of objects containing RuleArn, ErrorCode, and ErrorMessage. This parameter tells you which automation rules the request didn't update and why.

FindingIdentifiers.documentation:
The list of findings to update. BatchUpdateFindings can be used to update up to 100 findings at a time.

For each finding, the list provides the finding identifier and the ARN of the finding provider.

VerificationState.documentation:
Indicates the veracity of a finding.

The available values for VerificationState are as follows.

  • UNKNOWN – The default disposition of a security finding

  • TRUE_POSITIVE – The security finding is confirmed

  • FALSE_POSITIVE – The security finding was determined to be a false alarm

  • BENIGN_POSITIVE – A special case of TRUE_POSITIVE where the finding doesn't pose any threat, is expected, or both

Confidence.documentation:
The updated value for the finding confidence. Confidence is defined as the likelihood that a finding accurately identifies the behavior or issue that it was intended to identify.

Confidence is scored on a 0-100 basis using a ratio scale, where 0 means zero percent confidence and 100 means 100 percent confidence.

Criticality.documentation:
The updated value for the level of importance assigned to the resources associated with the findings.

A score of 0 means that the underlying resources have no criticality, and a score of 100 is reserved for the most critical resources.

Types.documentation:
One or more finding types in the format of namespace/category/classifier that classify a finding.

Valid namespace values are as follows.

  • Software and Configuration Checks

  • TTPs

  • Effects

  • Unusual Behaviors

  • Sensitive Data Identifications

UserDefinedFields.documentation: A list of name/value string pairs associated with the finding. These are custom, user-defined fields added to a finding.

Workflow.documentation:
Used to update the workflow status of a finding.

The workflow status indicates the progress of the investigation into the finding.

RelatedFindings.documentation: A list of findings that are related to the updated findings.

ProcessedFindings.documentation: The list of findings that were updated successfully.

UnprocessedFindings.documentation: The list of findings that were not updated.

FindingIdentifier.documentation: The identifier of the finding that was not updated.

ErrorCode.documentation:
The code associated with the error. Possible values are:

  • ConcurrentUpdateError - Another request attempted to update the finding while this request was being processed. This error may also occur if you call BatchUpdateFindings and BatchImportFindings at the same time.

  • DuplicatedFindingIdentifier - The request included two or more findings with the same FindingIdentifier.

  • FindingNotFound - The FindingIdentifier included in the request did not match an existing finding.

  • FindingSizeExceeded - The finding size was greater than the permissible value of 240 KB.

  • InternalFailure - An internal service failure occurred when updating the finding.

  • InvalidInput - The finding update contained an invalid value that did not satisfy the Amazon Web Services Security Finding Format syntax.

ErrorMessage.documentation:
The message associated with the error. Possible values are:

  • Concurrent finding updates detected

  • Finding Identifier is duplicated

  • Finding Not Found

  • Finding size exceeded 240 KB

  • Internal service failure

  • Invalid Input

BatchUpdateFindingsUnprocessedFinding.documentation: A finding from a BatchUpdateFindings request that Security Hub was unable to update.

FindingIdentifier.documentation: The finding identifier of a processed finding.

BatchUpdateFindingsV2ProcessedFinding.documentation: The list of findings that were updated.

MetadataUids.documentation: The list of finding metadata.uid to indicate findings to update. Finding metadata.uid is a globally unique identifier associated with the finding. Customers cannot use MetadataUids together with FindingIdentifiers.

FindingIdentifiers.documentation: Provides information to identify a specific V2 finding.

Comment.documentation: The updated value for a user provided comment about the finding. Minimum character length 1. Maximum character length 512.

SeverityId.documentation: The updated value for the normalized severity identifier. The severity ID is an integer with the allowed enum values [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 99]. When customer provides the updated severity ID, the string sibling severity will automatically be updated in the finding.

StatusId.documentation: The updated value for the normalized status identifier. The status ID is an integer with the allowed enum values [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 99]. When customer provides the updated status ID, the string sibling status will automatically be updated in the finding.

ProcessedFindings.documentation: The list of findings that were updated successfully.

UnprocessedFindings.documentation: The list of V2 findings that were not updated.

FindingIdentifier.documentation: The finding identifier of an unprocessed finding.

ErrorCode.documentation: Indicates the specific type of error preventing successful processing of a finding during a batch update operation.

ErrorMessage.documentation: A detailed description of why a finding could not be processed during a batch update operation.

BatchUpdateFindingsV2UnprocessedFinding.documentation: The list of findings that were not updated.

StandardsControlAssociationUpdates.documentation:
Updates the enablement status of a security control in a specified standard.

Calls to this operation return a RESOURCE_NOT_FOUND_EXCEPTION error when the standard subscription for the control has StandardsControlsUpdatable value NOT_READY_FOR_UPDATES.

UnprocessedAssociationUpdates.documentation: A security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) whose enablement status in a specified standard couldn't be updated.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a boolean parameter.

BooleanConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter with a boolean. For a boolean parameter, the options are true and false.

Column.documentation: The column number of the column that contains the data. For a Microsoft Excel workbook, the column number corresponds to the alphabetical column identifiers. For example, a value of 1 for Column corresponds to the A column in the workbook.

Row.documentation: The row number of the row that contains the data.

ColumnName.documentation: The name of the column that contains the data.

CellReference.documentation: For a Microsoft Excel workbook, provides the location of the cell, as an absolute cell reference, that contains the data. For example, Sheet2!C5 for cell C5 on Sheet2.

Cell.documentation: An occurrence of sensitive data detected in a Microsoft Excel workbook, comma-separated value (CSV) file, or tab-separated value (TSV) file.

AssociationId.documentation: The association ID for the IPv4 CIDR block.

CidrBlockState.documentation: Information about the state of the IPv4 CIDR block.

MimeType.documentation: The type of content that the finding applies to.

SizeClassified.documentation: The total size in bytes of the affected data.

AdditionalOccurrences.documentation: Indicates whether there are additional occurrences of sensitive data that are not included in the finding. This occurs when the number of occurrences exceeds the maximum that can be included.

Status.documentation: The current status of the sensitive data detection.

SensitiveData.documentation: Provides details about sensitive data that was identified based on built-in configuration.

CustomDataIdentifiers.documentation: Provides details about sensitive data that was identified based on customer-defined configuration.

ClassificationResult.documentation: Details about the sensitive data that was detected on the resource.

Code.documentation: The code that represents the status of the sensitive data detection.

Reason.documentation: A longer description of the current status of the sensitive data detection.

ClassificationStatus.documentation: Provides details about the current status of the sensitive data detection.

CloudWatchLogsLogGroupArn.documentation: The ARN of the CloudWatch Logs log group that Route 53 is publishing logs to.

HostedZoneId.documentation: The ID of the hosted zone that CloudWatch Logs is logging queries for.

Id.documentation: The ID for a DNS query logging configuration.

CloudWatchLogsLogGroupArnConfigDetails.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) and other details of the Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group that Amazon Route 53 is publishing logs to.

ProjectName.documentation: The name of the project in the code repository.

CodeSecurityIntegrationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the code security integration associated with the repository.

CodeRepositoryDetails.documentation: Details about an external code repository with which you can connect your Amazon Web Services resources. The connection is established through Amazon Inspector.

EndLine.documentation: The line number of the last line of code in which the vulnerability is located.

FileName.documentation: The name of the file in which the code vulnerability is located.

FilePath.documentation: The file path to the code in which the vulnerability is located.

StartLine.documentation: The line number of the first line of code in which the vulnerability is located.

CodeVulnerabilitiesFilePath.documentation: Provides details about where a code vulnerability is located in your Lambda function.

Status.documentation:
Typically summarizes the result of a control check.

For Security Hub controls, valid values for Status are as follows.

    • PASSED - Standards check passed for all evaluated resources.

    • WARNING - Some information is missing or this check is not supported for your configuration.

    • FAILED - Standards check failed for at least one evaluated resource.

    • NOT_AVAILABLE - Check could not be performed due to a service outage, API error, or because the result of the Config evaluation was NOT_APPLICABLE. If the Config evaluation result was NOT_APPLICABLE for a Security Hub control, Security Hub automatically archives the finding after 3 days.

RelatedRequirements.documentation:
Typically provides the industry or regulatory framework requirements that are related to a control. The check for that control is aligned with these requirements.

Array Members: Maximum number of 32 items.

StatusReasons.documentation: Typically used to provide a list of reasons for the value of Status.

SecurityControlId.documentation: Typically provides the unique identifier of a control across standards. For Security Hub controls, this field consists of an Amazon Web Services service and a unique number, such as APIGateway.5.

AssociatedStandards.documentation: Typically provides an array of enabled security standards in which a security control is currently enabled.

SecurityControlParameters.documentation: Typically an object that includes security control parameter names and values.

Compliance.documentation: This object typically provides details about a control finding, such as applicable standards and the status of control checks. While finding providers can add custom content in Compliance object fields, they are typically used to review details of Security Hub control findings.

StringFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on string field values.

DateFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on date and timestamp fields.

BooleanFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on boolean field values.

NumberFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on numerical field values.

MapFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on map field values.

Operator.documentation: The logical operator used to combine multiple filter conditions.

CompositeFilter.documentation: Enables the creation of filtering criteria for security findings.

Integer.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is an integer.

IntegerList.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a list of integers.

Double.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a double.

String.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a string data type.

StringList.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a list of strings.

Boolean.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a boolean. For a boolean parameter, the options are true and false.

Enum.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is an enum.

EnumList.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a list of enums.

ConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter.

Target.documentation: The target account, organizational unit, or the root.

ConfigurationPolicyAssociation.documentation: Provides details about the association between an Security Hub configuration and a target account, organizational unit, or the root. An association can exist between a target and a configuration policy, or between a target and self-managed behavior.

ConfigurationPolicyId.documentation: The universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

TargetId.documentation: The identifier of the target account, organizational unit, or the root.

TargetType.documentation: Specifies whether the target is an Amazon Web Services account, organizational unit, or the root.

AssociationType.documentation: Indicates whether the association between the specified target and the configuration was directly applied by the Security Hub delegated administrator or inherited from a parent.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy association was last updated.

AssociationStatus.documentation: The current status of the association between the specified target and the configuration.

AssociationStatusMessage.documentation: The explanation for a FAILED value for AssociationStatus.

ConfigurationPolicyAssociationSummary.documentation: An object that contains the details of a configuration policy association that’s returned in a ListConfigurationPolicyAssociations request.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration policy.

Id.documentation: The universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy. Alphanumeric characters and the following ASCII characters are permitted: -, ., !, *, /.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was last updated.

ServiceEnabled.documentation: Indicates whether the service that the configuration policy applies to is enabled in the policy.

ConfigurationPolicySummary.documentation: An object that contains the details of an Security Hub configuration policy that’s returned in a ListConfigurationPolicies request.

ConflictException.documentation: The request causes conflict with the current state of the service resource.

AuthCode.documentation: The authCode retrieved from authUrl to complete the OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow.

AuthState.documentation: The authState retrieved from authUrl to complete the OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow.

ConnectorArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the connectorV2.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

ConnectorArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the connectorV2.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

Name.documentation: The Name field contains the user-defined name assigned to the integration connector. This helps identify and manage multiple connectors within Security Hub.

ProviderSummary.documentation: The connectorV2 third party provider configuration summary.

CreatedAt.documentation: ISO 8601 UTC timestamp for the time create the connectorV2.

Name.documentation: The name of the container related to a finding.

ImageId.documentation: The identifier of the container image related to a finding.

ImageName.documentation: The name of the container image related to a finding.

LaunchedAt.documentation:
Indicates when the container started.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

VolumeMounts.documentation: Provides information about the mounting of a volume in a container.

Privileged.documentation: When this parameter is true, the container is given elevated privileges on the host container instance (similar to the root user).

CountryCode.documentation: The 2-letter ISO 3166 country code for the country.

Name.documentation: The name of the custom action target. Can contain up to 20 characters.

Description.documentation: The description for the custom action target.

Id.documentation: The ID for the custom action target. Can contain up to 20 alphanumeric characters.

ActionTargetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the custom action target.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Determines how Regions are linked to an Aggregator V2.

LinkedRegions.documentation: The list of Regions that are linked to the aggregation Region.

Tags.documentation: A list of key-value pairs to be applied to the AggregatorV2.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique identifier used to ensure idempotency.

AggregationRegion.documentation: The Amazon Web Services Region where data is aggregated.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Determines how Regions are linked to an Aggregator V2.

LinkedRegions.documentation: The list of Regions that are linked to the aggregation Region.

Tags.documentation: User-defined tags associated with an automation rule.

RuleStatus.documentation: Whether the rule is active after it is created. If this parameter is equal to ENABLED, Security Hub starts applying the rule to findings and finding updates after the rule is created. To change the value of this parameter after creating a rule, use BatchUpdateAutomationRules .

RuleOrder.documentation: An integer ranging from 1 to 1000 that represents the order in which the rule action is applied to findings. Security Hub applies rules with lower values for this parameter first.

IsTerminal.documentation: Specifies whether a rule is the last to be applied with respect to a finding that matches the rule criteria. This is useful when a finding matches the criteria for multiple rules, and each rule has different actions. If a rule is terminal, Security Hub applies the rule action to a finding that matches the rule criteria and doesn't evaluate other rules for the finding. By default, a rule isn't terminal.

Criteria.documentation: A set of ASFF finding field attributes and corresponding expected values that Security Hub uses to filter findings. If a rule is enabled and a finding matches the conditions specified in this parameter, Security Hub applies the rule action to the finding.

Actions.documentation: One or more actions to update finding fields if a finding matches the conditions specified in Criteria.

RuleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the automation rule that you created.

RuleName.documentation: The name of the V2 automation rule.

RuleStatus.documentation: The status of the V2 automation rule.

Description.documentation: A description of the V2 automation rule.

Criteria.documentation: The filtering type and configuration of the automation rule.

Actions.documentation: A list of actions to be performed when the rule criteria is met.

Tags.documentation: A list of key-value pairs associated with the V2 automation rule.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique identifier used to ensure idempotency.

RuleArn.documentation: The ARN of the V2 automation rule.

RuleId.documentation: The ID of the V2 automation rule.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy. Alphanumeric characters and the following ASCII characters are permitted: -, ., !, *, /.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

ConfigurationPolicy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If you provide a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If you provide a list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

Tags.documentation: User-defined tags associated with a configuration policy. For more information, see Tagging Security Hub resources in the Security Hub user guide.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration policy.

Id.documentation: The universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was last updated.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was created.

ConfigurationPolicy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If the request included a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If the request included a list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

Name.documentation: The unique name of the connectorV2.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of KMS key used to encrypt secrets for the connectorV2.

Tags.documentation: The tags to add to the connectorV2 when you create.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique identifier used to ensure idempotency.

ConnectorArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the connectorV2.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

AuthUrl.documentation: The Url provide to customers for OAuth auth code flow.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation:
Indicates whether to aggregate findings from all of the available Regions in the current partition. Also determines whether to automatically aggregate findings from new Regions as Security Hub supports them and you opt into them.

The selected option also determines how to use the Regions provided in the Regions list.

The options are as follows:

  • ALL_REGIONS - Aggregates findings from all of the Regions where Security Hub is enabled. When you choose this option, Security Hub also automatically aggregates findings from new Regions as Security Hub supports them and you opt into them.

  • ALL_REGIONS_EXCEPT_SPECIFIED - Aggregates findings from all of the Regions where Security Hub is enabled, except for the Regions listed in the Regions parameter. When you choose this option, Security Hub also automatically aggregates findings from new Regions as Security Hub supports them and you opt into them.

  • SPECIFIED_REGIONS - Aggregates findings only from the Regions listed in the Regions parameter. Security Hub does not automatically aggregate findings from new Regions.

  • NO_REGIONS - Aggregates no data because no Regions are selected as linked Regions.

Regions.documentation:
If RegionLinkingMode is ALL_REGIONS_EXCEPT_SPECIFIED, then this is a space-separated list of Regions that don't replicate and send findings to the home Region.

If RegionLinkingMode is SPECIFIED_REGIONS, then this is a space-separated list of Regions that do replicate and send findings to the home Region.

An InvalidInputException error results if you populate this field while RegionLinkingMode is NO_REGIONS.

FindingAggregatorArn.documentation: The ARN of the finding aggregator. You use the finding aggregator ARN to retrieve details for, update, and stop cross-Region aggregation.

FindingAggregationRegion.documentation: The home Region. Findings generated in linked Regions are replicated and sent to the home Region.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Indicates whether to link all Regions, all Regions except for a list of excluded Regions, or a list of included Regions.

Regions.documentation: The list of excluded Regions or included Regions.

Name.documentation: The name of the custom insight to create.

Filters.documentation: One or more attributes used to filter the findings included in the insight. The insight only includes findings that match the criteria defined in the filters.

GroupByAttribute.documentation: The attribute used to group the findings for the insight. The grouping attribute identifies the type of item that the insight applies to. For example, if an insight is grouped by resource identifier, then the insight produces a list of resource identifiers.

AccountDetails.documentation: The list of accounts to associate with the Security Hub administrator account. For each account, the list includes the account ID and optionally the email address.

UnprocessedAccounts.documentation: The list of Amazon Web Services accounts that were not processed. For each account, the list includes the account ID and the email address.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

FindingMetadataUid.documentation: The the unique ID for the finding.

OcsfFindingCriteria.documentation: The filtering conditions that align with OCSF standards.

Criteria.documentation: Defines the parameters and conditions used to evaluate and filter security findings.

Count.documentation: The total number of occurrences of sensitive data that were detected.

Arn.documentation: The ARN of the custom identifier that was used to detect the sensitive data.

Name.documentation: he name of the custom identifier that detected the sensitive data.

Occurrences.documentation: Details about the sensitive data that was detected.

CustomDataIdentifiersDetections.documentation: The list of detected instances of sensitive data.

Detections.documentation: The list of detected instances of sensitive data.

TotalCount.documentation: The total number of occurrences of sensitive data.

CustomDataIdentifiersResult.documentation: Contains an instance of sensitive data that was detected by a customer-defined identifier.

Version.documentation: The version of CVSS for the CVSS score.

BaseVector.documentation: The base scoring vector for the CVSS score.

Source.documentation: The origin of the original CVSS score and vector.

Cvss.documentation: CVSS scores from the advisory related to the vulnerability.

DetailedResultsLocation.documentation: The path to the folder or file that contains the sensitive data.

Result.documentation: The details about the sensitive data that was detected on the resource.

DataClassificationDetails.documentation: Provides details about sensitive data that was detected on a resource.

Start.documentation:
A timestamp that provides the start date for the date filter.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

End.documentation:
A timestamp that provides the end date for the date filter.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

DateRange.documentation: A date range for the date filter.

Value.documentation: A date range value for the date filter.

Unit.documentation: A date range unit for the date filter.

DateRange.documentation: A date range for the date filter.

AccountIds.documentation: The list of prospective member account IDs for which to decline an invitation.

UnprocessedAccounts.documentation: The list of Amazon Web Services accounts that were not processed. For each account, the list includes the account ID and the email address.

ActionTargetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom action target to delete.
The ARN of the custom action target that was deleted.

Identifier.documentation: The ARN of the V2 automation rule.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

FindingAggregatorArn.documentation: The ARN of the finding aggregator to delete. To obtain the ARN, use ListFindingAggregators.

InsightArn.documentation: The ARN of the insight to delete.
The ARN of the insight that was deleted.

AccountIds.documentation: The list of member account IDs that received the invitations you want to delete.

UnprocessedAccounts.documentation: The list of Amazon Web Services accounts for which the invitations were not deleted. For each account, the list includes the account ID and the email address.

AccountIds.documentation: The list of account IDs for the member accounts to delete.

UnprocessedAccounts.documentation: The list of Amazon Web Services accounts that were not deleted. For each account, the list includes the account ID and the email address.

ActionTargetArns.documentation: A list of custom action target ARNs for the custom action targets to retrieve.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the DescribeActionTargets operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return.

ActionTargets.documentation: A list of ActionTarget objects. Each object includes the ActionTargetArn, Description, and Name of a custom action target available in Security Hub.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

HubArn.documentation: The ARN of the Hub resource to retrieve.
The ARN of the Hub resource that was retrieved.

SubscribedAt.documentation: The date and time when Security Hub was enabled in the account.

AutoEnableControls.documentation:
Whether to automatically enable new controls when they are added to standards that are enabled.

If set to true, then new controls for enabled standards are enabled automatically. If set to false, then new controls are not enabled.

When you automatically enable new controls, you can interact with the controls in the console and programmatically immediately after release. However, automatically enabled controls have a temporary default status of DISABLED. It can take up to several days for Security Hub to process the control release and designate the control as ENABLED in your account. During the processing period, you can manually enable or disable a control, and Security Hub will maintain that designation regardless of whether you have AutoEnableControls set to true.

ControlFindingGenerator.documentation:
Specifies whether the calling account has consolidated control findings turned on. If the value for this field is set to SECURITY_CONTROL, Security Hub generates a single finding for a control check even when the check applies to multiple enabled standards.

If the value for this field is set to STANDARD_CONTROL, Security Hub generates separate findings for a control check when the check applies to multiple enabled standards.

The value for this field in a member account matches the value in the administrator account. For accounts that aren't part of an organization, the default value of this field is SECURITY_CONTROL if you enabled Security Hub on or after February 23, 2023.

AutoEnable.documentation:
Whether to automatically enable Security Hub in new member accounts when they join the organization.

If set to true, then Security Hub is automatically enabled in new accounts. If set to false, then Security Hub isn't enabled in new accounts automatically. The default value is false.

If the ConfigurationType of your organization is set to CENTRAL, then this field is set to false and can't be changed in the home Region and linked Regions. However, in that case, the delegated administrator can create a configuration policy in which Security Hub is enabled and associate the policy with new organization accounts.

MemberAccountLimitReached.documentation: Whether the maximum number of allowed member accounts are already associated with the Security Hub administrator account.

AutoEnableStandards.documentation:
Whether to automatically enable Security Hub default standards in new member accounts when they join the organization.

If equal to DEFAULT, then Security Hub default standards are automatically enabled for new member accounts. If equal to NONE, then default standards are not automatically enabled for new member accounts. The default value of this parameter is equal to DEFAULT.

If the ConfigurationType of your organization is set to CENTRAL, then this field is set to NONE and can't be changed in the home Region and linked Regions. However, in that case, the delegated administrator can create a configuration policy in which specific security standards are enabled and associate the policy with new organization accounts.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the DescribeProducts operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return.

ProductArn.documentation: The ARN of the integration to return.

Products.documentation: A list of products, including details for each product.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

The token required for pagination. On your first call, set the value of this parameter to NULL. For subsequent calls, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned in the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results. Otherwise, this parameter is null.

SubscribedAt.documentation: The date and time when the service was enabled in the account.

StandardsSubscriptionArn.documentation: The ARN of a resource that represents your subscription to a supported standard. To get the subscription ARNs of the standards you have enabled, use the GetEnabledStandards operation.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the DescribeStandardsControls operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of security standard controls to return.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the DescribeStandards operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of standards to return.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

Sequence.documentation: Provides details about an attack sequence.

Detection.documentation: A top-level object field that provides details about an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

ProductSubscriptionArn.documentation: The ARN of the integrated product to disable the integration for.

AdminAccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account identifier of the Security Hub administrator account.

Feature.documentation: The feature for which the delegated admin account is disabled. Defaults to Security Hub if not specified.

AccountIds.documentation: The account IDs of the member accounts to disassociate from the administrator account.

Domain.documentation:
The DNS domain that is associated with the DNS request.

Length Constraints: 128.

Protocol.documentation:
The protocol that was used for the DNS request.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 64.

Blocked.documentation: Indicates whether the DNS request was blocked.

DnsRequestAction.documentation: Provided if ActionType is DNS_REQUEST. It provides details about the DNS request that was detected.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a control parameter that is a double.

Min.documentation: The minimum valid value for a control parameter that is a double.

Max.documentation: The maximum valid value for a control parameter that is a double.

DoubleConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a double.

ProductArn.documentation: The ARN of the product to enable the integration for.

ProductSubscriptionArn.documentation: The ARN of your subscription to the product to enable integrations for.

AdminAccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account identifier of the account to designate as the Security Hub administrator account.

Feature.documentation: The feature for which the delegated admin account is enabled. Defaults to Security Hub if not specified.

AdminAccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account identifier of the account to designate as the Security Hub administrator account.

Feature.documentation: The feature where the delegated administrator is enabled. The default is Security Hub CSPM if no delegated administrator is specified in the request.

Tags.documentation: The tags to add to the hub resource when you enable Security Hub.

EnableDefaultStandards.documentation: Whether to enable the security standards that Security Hub has designated as automatically enabled. If you don't provide a value for EnableDefaultStandards, it is set to true. To not enable the automatically enabled standards, set EnableDefaultStandards to false.

ControlFindingGenerator.documentation:
This field, used when enabling Security Hub, specifies whether the calling account has consolidated control findings turned on. If the value for this field is set to SECURITY_CONTROL, Security Hub generates a single finding for a control check even when the check applies to multiple enabled standards.

If the value for this field is set to STANDARD_CONTROL, Security Hub generates separate findings for a control check when the check applies to multiple enabled standards.

The value for this field in a member account matches the value in the administrator account. For accounts that aren't part of an organization, the default value of this field is SECURITY_CONTROL if you enabled Security Hub on or after February 23, 2023.

Tags.documentation: The tags to add to the hub V2 resource when you enable Security Hub.

HubV2Arn.documentation: The ARN of the V2 resource that was created.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a control parameter that is an enum.

AllowedValues.documentation: The valid values for a control parameter that is an enum.

EnumConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is an enum.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a control parameter that is a list of enums.

MaxItems.documentation: The maximum number of list items that an enum list control parameter can accept.

AllowedValues.documentation: The valid values for a control parameter that is a list of enums.

EnumListConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a list of enums.

ConnectorArn.documentation: The ARN of the connector that establishes the integration.

ExternalIntegrationConfiguration.documentation: Defines the settings and parameters required for integrating external security tools and services.

FilePath.documentation:
Path to the infected or suspicious file on the resource it was detected on.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

FileName.documentation:
The name of the infected or suspicious file corresponding to the hash.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

ResourceId.documentation:
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource on which the threat was detected.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

Hash.documentation:
The hash value for the infected or suspicious file.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

FilePaths.documentation: Provides information about the file paths that were affected by the threat.

FindingAggregatorArn.documentation: The ARN of the finding aggregator. You use the finding aggregator ARN to retrieve details for, update, and delete the finding aggregator.

FindingAggregator.documentation: A finding aggregator is a Security Hub resource that specifies cross-Region aggregation settings, including the home Region and any linked Regions.

UpdateTime.documentation:
A timestamp that indicates when Security Hub processed the updated finding record.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

FindingCreated.documentation: Identifies whether the event marks the creation of a new finding. A value of True means that the finding is newly created. A value of False means that the finding isn’t newly created.

UpdateSource.documentation: Identifies the source of the event that changed the finding. For example, an integrated Amazon Web Services service or third-party partner integration may call BatchImportFindings , or an Security Hub customer may call BatchUpdateFindings .

Updates.documentation: An array of objects that provides details about the finding change event, including the Amazon Web Services Security Finding Format (ASFF) field that changed, the value of the field before the change, and the value of the field after the change.

NextToken.documentation: A token for pagination purposes. Provide this token in the subsequent request to GetFindingsHistory to get up to an additional 100 results of history for the same finding that you specified in your initial request.

FindingHistoryRecord.documentation: A list of events that changed the specified finding during the specified time period. Each record represents a single finding change event.

UpdatedField.documentation: The ASFF field that changed during the finding change event.

OldValue.documentation: The value of the ASFF field before the finding change event.

NewValue.documentation: The value of the ASFF field after the finding change event. To preserve storage and readability, Security Hub omits this value if FindingHistoryRecord exceeds database limits.

FindingHistoryUpdate.documentation: An array of objects that provides details about a change to a finding, including the Amazon Web Services Security Finding Format (ASFF) field that changed, the value of the field before the change, and the value of the field after the change.

Type.documentation: Describes the type of finding change event, such as a call to BatchImportFindings (by an integrated Amazon Web Services service or third party partner integration) or BatchUpdateFindings (by a Security Hub customer).

Identity.documentation: The identity of the source that initiated the finding change event. For example, the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a partner that calls BatchImportFindings or of a customer that calls BatchUpdateFindings.

FindingHistoryUpdateSource.documentation: Identifies the source of the finding change event.

Confidence.documentation:
A finding's confidence. Confidence is defined as the likelihood that a finding accurately identifies the behavior or issue that it was intended to identify.

Confidence is scored on a 0-100 basis using a ratio scale, where 0 means zero percent confidence and 100 means 100 percent confidence.

Criticality.documentation:
The level of importance assigned to the resources associated with the finding.

A score of 0 means that the underlying resources have no criticality, and a score of 100 is reserved for the most critical resources.

RelatedFindings.documentation: A list of findings that are related to the current finding.

Types.documentation:
One or more finding types in the format of namespace/category/classifier that classify a finding.

Valid namespace values are: Software and Configuration Checks | TTPs | Effects | Unusual Behaviors | Sensitive Data Identifications

FindingProviderFields.documentation:
In a BatchImportFindings request, finding providers use FindingProviderFields to provide and update values for the following fields:

  • Confidence

  • Criticality

  • RelatedFindings

  • Severity

  • Types

The preceding fields are nested under the FindingProviderFields object, but also have analogues of the same name as top-level ASFF fields. When a new finding is sent to Security Hub by a finding provider, Security Hub populates the FindingProviderFields object automatically, if it is empty, based on the corresponding top-level fields.

Finding providers can update FindingProviderFields only by using the BatchImportFindings operation. Finding providers can't update this object with the BatchUpdateFindings operation. Customers can update the top-level fields by using the BatchUpdateFindings operation. Customers can't update FindingProviderFields.

For information about how Security Hub handles updates from BatchImportFindings to FindingProviderFields and to the corresponding top-level attributes, see Using FindingProviderFields in the Security Hub User Guide.

Label.documentation: The severity label assigned to the finding by the finding provider.

Original.documentation:
The finding provider's original value for the severity.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 64.

FindingProviderSeverity.documentation:
The severity assigned to a finding by the finding provider. This object may include one or more of the following attributes:

  • Label

  • Normalized

  • Original

  • Product

If a BatchImportFindings request for a new finding only provides Label or only provides Normalized, Security Hub automatically populates the value of the other field.

The Normalized and Product attributes are included in the FindingProviderSeverity structure to preserve the historical information associated with the finding, even if the top-level Severity object is later modified using the BatchUpdateFindings operation.

If the top-level Finding.Severity object is present, but Finding.FindingProviderFields isn't present, Security Hub creates the FindingProviderFields.Severity object and copies the entire Finding.Severity object into it. This ensures that the original, provider-supplied details are retained within the FindingProviderFields.Severity object, even if the top-level Severity object is overwritten.

StatefulRuleGroupReferences.documentation: The stateful rule groups that are used in the firewall policy.

StatelessCustomActions.documentation: The custom action definitions that are available to use in the firewall policy's StatelessDefaultActions setting.

StatelessDefaultActions.documentation:
The actions to take on a packet if it doesn't match any of the stateless rules in the policy.

You must specify a standard action (aws:pass, aws:drop, aws:forward_to_sfe), and can optionally include a custom action from StatelessCustomActions.

StatelessFragmentDefaultActions.documentation:
The actions to take on a fragmented UDP packet if it doesn't match any of the stateless rules in the policy.

You must specify a standard action (aws:pass, aws:drop, aws:forward_to_sfe), and can optionally include a custom action from StatelessCustomActions.

StatelessRuleGroupReferences.documentation: The stateless rule groups that are used in the firewall policy.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the stateful rule group.

FirewallPolicyStatefulRuleGroupReference.documentation: A stateful rule group that is used by the firewall policy.

FirewallPolicyStatelessCustomActionsDeta.documentation: A custom action that can be used for stateless packet handling.

Priority.documentation: The order in which to run the stateless rule group.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the stateless rule group.

FirewallPolicyStatelessRuleGroupReferenc.documentation: A stateless rule group that is used by the firewall policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the detector used to identify the code vulnerability.

Description.documentation: The description of the detector used to identify the code vulnerability.

Labels.documentation:
An array of tags used to identify the detector associated with the finding.

Array Members: Minimum number of 0 items. Maximum number of 10 items.

GeneratorDetails.documentation: Provides metadata for the Amazon CodeGuru detector associated with a finding. This field pertains to findings that relate to Lambda functions. Amazon Inspector identifies policy violations and vulnerabilities in Lambda function code based on internal detectors developed in collaboration with Amazon CodeGuru. Security Hub receives those findings.

GeoLocation.documentation: Provides the latitude and longitude coordinates of a location.

AggregationRegion.documentation: The Amazon Web Services Region where data is aggregated.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Determines how Regions are linked to an Aggregator V2.

LinkedRegions.documentation: The list of Regions that are linked to the aggregation Region.

Identifier.documentation: The ARN of the V2 automation rule.

RuleArn.documentation: The ARN of the V2 automation rule.

RuleId.documentation: The ID of the V2 automation rule.

RuleName.documentation: The name of the V2 automation rule.

RuleStatus.documentation: The status of the V2 automation automation rule.

Criteria.documentation: The filtering type and configuration of the V2 automation rule.

Actions.documentation: A list of actions performed when the rule criteria is met.

CreatedAt.documentation: The timestamp when the V2 automation rule was created.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp when the V2 automation rule was updated.

Target.documentation: The target account ID, organizational unit ID, or the root ID to retrieve the association for.

ConfigurationPolicyId.documentation: The universally unique identifier (UUID) of a configuration policy. For self-managed behavior, the value is SELF_MANAGED_SECURITY_HUB.

TargetId.documentation: The target account ID, organizational unit ID, or the root ID for which the association is retrieved.

TargetType.documentation: Specifies whether the target is an Amazon Web Services account, organizational unit, or the organization root.

AssociationType.documentation: Indicates whether the association between the specified target and the configuration was directly applied by the Security Hub delegated administrator or inherited from a parent.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy association was last updated.

AssociationStatus.documentation: The current status of the association between the specified target and the configuration.

AssociationStatusMessage.documentation: The explanation for a FAILED value for AssociationStatus.

Identifier.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

Arn.documentation: The ARN of the configuration policy.

Id.documentation: The UUID of the configuration policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was last updated.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was created.

ConfigurationPolicy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If the policy includes a list of security controls that are enabled, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If the policy includes a list of security controls that are disabled, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

ConnectorArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the connectorV2.

ConnectorId.documentation: The UUID of the connectorV2 to identify connectorV2 resource.

Name.documentation: The name of the connectorV2.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of KMS key used for the connectorV2.

CreatedAt.documentation: ISO 8601 UTC timestamp for the time create the connectorV2.

LastUpdatedAt.documentation: ISO 8601 UTC timestamp for the time update the connectorV2 connectorStatus.

ProviderDetail.documentation: The third-party provider detail for a service configuration.

StandardsSubscriptionArns.documentation: The list of the standards subscription ARNs for the standards to retrieve.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the GetEnabledStandards operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in the response.

StandardsSubscriptions.documentation: The list of StandardsSubscriptions objects that include information about the enabled standards.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

FindingAggregatorArn.documentation: The ARN of the finding aggregator to return details for. To obtain the ARN, use ListFindingAggregators.

FindingAggregationRegion.documentation: The home Region. Findings generated in linked Regions are replicated and sent to the home Region.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Indicates whether to link all Regions, all Regions except for a list of excluded Regions, or a list of included Regions.

Regions.documentation: The list of excluded Regions or included Regions.

StartTime.documentation:
A timestamp that indicates the start time of the requested finding history.

If you provide values for both StartTime and EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history for the specified time period. If you provide a value for StartTime but not for EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the StartTime to the time at which the API is called. If you provide a value for EndTime but not for StartTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the CreatedAt timestamp of the finding to the EndTime. If you provide neither StartTime nor EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the CreatedAt timestamp of the finding to the time at which the API is called. In all of these scenarios, the response is limited to 100 results.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

EndTime.documentation:
An ISO 8601-formatted timestamp that indicates the end time of the requested finding history.

If you provide values for both StartTime and EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history for the specified time period. If you provide a value for StartTime but not for EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the StartTime to the time at which the API is called. If you provide a value for EndTime but not for StartTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the CreatedAt timestamp of the finding to the EndTime. If you provide neither StartTime nor EndTime, Security Hub returns finding history from the CreatedAt timestamp of the finding to the time at which the API is called. In all of these scenarios, the response is limited to 100 results.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

NextToken.documentation: A token for pagination purposes. Provide NULL as the initial value. In subsequent requests, provide the token included in the response to get up to an additional 100 results of finding history. If you don’t provide NextToken, Security Hub returns up to 100 results of finding history for each request.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to be returned. If you don’t provide it, Security Hub returns up to 100 results of finding history.

Records.documentation: A list of events that altered the specified finding during the specified time period.

NextToken.documentation: A token for pagination purposes. Provide this token in the subsequent request to GetFindingsHistory to get up to an additional 100 results of history for the same finding that you specified in your initial request.

GroupByRules.documentation: Specifies how security findings should be aggregated and organized in the statistical analysis. It can accept up to 5 groupBy fields in a single call.

SortOrder.documentation: Orders the aggregation count in descending or ascending order. Descending order is the default.

MaxStatisticResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to be returned.

GroupByResults.documentation: Aggregated statistics about security findings based on specified grouping criteria.

Filters.documentation:
The finding attributes used to define a condition to filter the returned findings.

You can filter by up to 10 finding attributes. For each attribute, you can provide up to 20 filter values.

Note that in the available filter fields, WorkflowState is deprecated. To search for a finding based on its workflow status, use WorkflowStatus.

SortCriteria.documentation: The finding attributes used to sort the list of returned findings.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the GetFindings operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of findings to return.

Findings.documentation: The findings that matched the filters specified in the request.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

Filters.documentation: The finding attributes used to define a condition to filter the returned OCSF findings. You can filter up to 10 composite filters. For each filter type inside of a composite filter, you can provide up to 20 filters.

SortCriteria.documentation: The finding attributes used to sort the list of returned findings.

NextToken.documentation: The token required for pagination. On your first call, set the value of this parameter to NULL. For subsequent calls, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned in the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return.

Findings.documentation: An array of security findings returned by the operation.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results. Otherwise, this parameter is null.

InsightArn.documentation: The ARN of the insight for which to return results.

InsightResults.documentation: The insight results returned by the operation.

InsightArns.documentation: The ARNs of the insights to describe. If you don't provide any insight ARNs, then GetInsights returns all of your custom insights. It does not return any managed insights.

NextToken.documentation:
The token that is required for pagination. On your first call to the GetInsights operation, set the value of this parameter to NULL.

For subsequent calls to the operation, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned from the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of items to return in the response.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results.

InvitationsCount.documentation: The number of all membership invitations sent to this Security Hub member account, not including the currently accepted invitation.

Master.documentation: A list of details about the Security Hub administrator account for the current member account.

AccountIds.documentation: The list of account IDs for the Security Hub member accounts to return the details for.

Members.documentation: The list of details about the Security Hub member accounts.

UnprocessedAccounts.documentation: The list of Amazon Web Services accounts that could not be processed. For each account, the list includes the account ID and the email address.

GroupByRules.documentation: How resource statistics should be aggregated and organized in the response.

MaxStatisticResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to be returned.

GroupByResults.documentation: The aggregated statistics about resources based on the specified grouping rule.

Filters.documentation: Filters resources based on a set of criteria.

SortCriteria.documentation: The finding attributes used to sort the list of returned findings.

NextToken.documentation: The token required for pagination. On your first call, set the value of this parameter to NULL. For subsequent calls, to continue listing data, set the value of this parameter to the value returned in the previous response.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return.

Resources.documentation: Filters resources based on a set of criteria.

NextToken.documentation: The pagination token to use to request the next page of results. Otherwise, this parameter is null.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The ID of the security control to retrieve the definition for. This field doesn’t accept an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

GroupByField.documentation: The attribute by which filtered security findings should be grouped.

GroupByValues.documentation: An array of grouped values and their respective counts for each GroupByField.

Filters.documentation: The criteria used to select which security findings should be included in the grouping operation.

GroupByField.documentation: The attribute by which filtered findings should be grouped.

GroupByRule.documentation: Defines the how the finding attribute should be grouped.

FieldValue.documentation: The value of the field by which findings are grouped.

Count.documentation: The number of findings for a specific FieldValue and GroupByField.

GroupByValue.documentation: Represents individual aggregated results when grouping security findings for each GroupByField.

Message.documentation: The message for the reason of connectorStatus change.

LastCheckedAt.documentation: ISO 8601 UTC timestamp for the time check the health status of the connectorV2.

HealthCheck.documentation: Information about the operational status and health of a connectorV2.

Code.documentation: The ICMP code for which to deny or allow access. To deny or allow all codes, use the value -1.

Type.documentation: The ICMP type for which to deny or allow access. To deny or allow all types, use the value -1.

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: An Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) type and code.

Id.documentation: The identifier of the finding that could not be updated.

ErrorCode.documentation: The code of the error returned by the BatchImportFindings operation.

ErrorMessage.documentation: The message of the error returned by the BatchImportFindings operation.

ImportFindingsError.documentation: The list of the findings that cannot be imported. For each finding, the list provides the error.

Key.documentation: The name of the indicator that’s present in the attack sequence finding.

Values.documentation: Values associated with each indicator key. For example, if the indicator key is SUSPICIOUS_NETWORK, then the value will be the name of the network. If the indicator key is ATTACK_TACTIC, then the value will be one of the MITRE tactics.

Type.documentation: The type of indicator.

Indicator.documentation: Contains information about the indicators observed in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. Indicators include a set of signals, which can be API activities or findings that GuardDuty uses to detect an attack sequence finding. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple signals align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty and GuardDuty S3 Protection enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

InsightArn.documentation: The ARN of a Security Hub insight.

Name.documentation: The name of a Security Hub insight.

Filters.documentation: One or more attributes used to filter the findings included in the insight. You can filter by up to ten finding attributes. For each attribute, you can provide up to 20 filter values. The insight only includes findings that match the criteria defined in the filters.

GroupByAttribute.documentation: The grouping attribute for the insight's findings. Indicates how to group the matching findings, and identifies the type of item that the insight applies to. For example, if an insight is grouped by resource identifier, then the insight produces a list of resource identifiers.

Insight.documentation: Contains information about a Security Hub insight.

GroupByAttributeValue.documentation: The value of the attribute that the findings are grouped by for the insight whose results are returned by the GetInsightResults operation.

Count.documentation: The number of findings returned for each GroupByAttributeValue.

InsightResultValue.documentation: The insight result values returned by the GetInsightResults operation.

InsightArn.documentation: The ARN of the insight whose results are returned by the GetInsightResults operation.

GroupByAttribute.documentation: The attribute that the findings are grouped by for the insight whose results are returned by the GetInsightResults operation.

If OnlyAssociated is set to TRUE, the response includes member accounts whose relationship status with the administrator account is set to ENABLED.

If OnlyAssociated is set to FALSE, the response includes all existing member accounts.

The results also include a NextToken parameter that you can use in a subsequent API call to get the next 25 associations. This repeats until all associations for the specified control are returned. The number of results is limited by the number of supported Security Hub standards that you've enabled in the calling account.

The state code. The initial state of the load balancer is provisioning.

After the load balancer is fully set up and ready to route traffic, its state is active.

If the load balancer could not be set up, its state is failed.

The name of the malware that was observed.

Key.documentation: The key of the map filter. For example, for ResourceTags, Key identifies the name of the tag. For UserDefinedFields, Key is the name of the field.

Value.documentation: The value for the key in the map filter. Filter values are case sensitive. For example, one of the values for a tag called Department might be Security. If you provide security as the filter value, then there's no match.

Comparison.documentation:
The condition to apply to the key value when filtering Security Hub findings with a map filter.

To search for values that have the filter value, use one of the following comparison operators:

  • To search for values that include the filter value, use CONTAINS. For example, for the ResourceTags field, the filter Department CONTAINS Security matches findings that include the value Security for the Department tag. In the same example, a finding with a value of Security team for the Department tag is a match.

  • To search for values that exactly match the filter value, use EQUALS. For example, for the ResourceTags field, the filter Department EQUALS Security matches findings that have the value Security for the Department tag.

CONTAINS and EQUALS filters on the same field are joined by OR. A finding matches if it matches any one of those filters. For example, the filters Department CONTAINS Security OR Department CONTAINS Finance match a finding that includes either Security, Finance, or both values.

To search for values that don't have the filter value, use one of the following comparison operators:

  • To search for values that exclude the filter value, use NOT_CONTAINS. For example, for the ResourceTags field, the filter Department NOT_CONTAINS Finance matches findings that exclude the value Finance for the Department tag.

  • To search for values other than the filter value, use NOT_EQUALS. For example, for the ResourceTags field, the filter Department NOT_EQUALS Finance matches findings that don’t have the value Finance for the Department tag.

NOT_CONTAINS and NOT_EQUALS filters on the same field are joined by AND. A finding matches only if it matches all of those filters. For example, the filters Department NOT_CONTAINS Security AND Department NOT_CONTAINS Finance match a finding that excludes both the Security and Finance values.

CONTAINS filters can only be used with other CONTAINS filters. NOT_CONTAINS filters can only be used with other NOT_CONTAINS filters.

You can’t have both a CONTAINS filter and a NOT_CONTAINS filter on the same field. Similarly, you can’t have both an EQUALS filter and a NOT_EQUALS filter on the same field. Combining filters in this way returns an error.

CONTAINS and NOT_CONTAINS operators can be used only with automation rules. For more information, see Automation rules in the Security Hub User Guide.

MapFilter.documentation: A map filter for filtering Security Hub findings. Each map filter provides the field to check for, the value to check for, and the comparison operator.

AccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the member account.

Email.documentation: The email address of the member account.

MasterId.documentation:
This is replaced by AdministratorID.

The Amazon Web Services account ID of the Security Hub administrator account associated with this member account.
MasterId.deprecatedMessage: This field is deprecated, use AdministratorId instead.

AdministratorId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the Security Hub administrator account associated with this member account.

MemberStatus.documentation:
The status of the relationship between the member account and its administrator account.

The status can have one of the following values:

  • Created - Indicates that the administrator account added the member account, but has not yet invited the member account.

  • Invited - Indicates that the administrator account invited the member account. The member account has not yet responded to the invitation.

  • Enabled - Indicates that the member account is currently active. For manually invited member accounts, indicates that the member account accepted the invitation.

  • Removed - Indicates that the administrator account disassociated the member account.

  • Resigned - Indicates that the member account disassociated themselves from the administrator account.

  • Deleted - Indicates that the administrator account deleted the member account.

  • AccountSuspended - Indicates that an organization account was suspended from Amazon Web Services at the same time that the administrator account tried to enable the organization account as a member account.

InvitedAt.documentation: A timestamp for the date and time when the invitation was sent to the member account.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp for the date and time when the member account was updated.

The destination domain of network-related information about a finding.

NetworkAutonomousSystem.documentation: Contains information about the Autonomous System (AS) of the network endpoints involved in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

Direction.documentation: The direction in which the network traffic is flowing.

NetworkConnection.documentation: Contains information about the network connection involved in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

Blocked.documentation: Indicates whether the network connection attempt was blocked.

NetworkConnectionAction.documentation: Provided if ActionType is NETWORK_CONNECTION. It provides details about the attempted network connection that was detected.

Ip.documentation: The IP address used in the network endpoint.

Domain.documentation: The domain information for the network endpoint.

Port.documentation: The port number associated with the network endpoint.

Contains information about network endpoints involved in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

This field can provide information about the network endpoints associated with the resource in the attack sequence finding, or about a specific network endpoint used for the attack.

Lat.documentation: The latitude information of the endpoint location.

Lon.documentation: The longitude information of the endpoint location.

NetworkGeoLocation.documentation: Contains information about the location of a network endpoint involved in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

The protocol used for the component.

The identifier of a component in the network path.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1. Maximum of 32.

The type of component.

The text of a note.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1. Maximum of 512.
