For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

Note.documentation: A user-defined note added to a finding.

Gte.documentation: The greater-than-equal condition to be applied to a single field when querying for findings.

Lte.documentation: The less-than-equal condition to be applied to a single field when querying for findings.

Eq.documentation: The equal-to condition to be applied to a single field when querying for findings.

Gt.documentation: The greater-than condition to be applied to a single field when querying for findings.

Lt.documentation: The less-than condition to be applied to a single field when querying for findings.

LineRanges.documentation: Occurrences of sensitive data detected in a non-binary text file or a Microsoft Word file. Non-binary text files include files such as HTML, XML, JSON, and TXT files.

OffsetRanges.documentation: Occurrences of sensitive data detected in a binary text file.

Pages.documentation: Occurrences of sensitive data in an Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) file.

Records.documentation: Occurrences of sensitive data in an Apache Avro object container or an Apache Parquet file.

Cells.documentation: Occurrences of sensitive data detected in Microsoft Excel workbooks, comma-separated value (CSV) files, or tab-separated value (TSV) files.

OcsfDateFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of security findings based on date and timestamp fields in OCSF.

CompositeFilters.documentation: Enables the creation of complex filtering conditions by combining filter criteria.

CompositeOperator.documentation: The logical operators used to combine the filtering on multiple CompositeFilters.

OcsfFindingFilters.documentation: Specifies the filtering criteria for security findings using OCSF.

CloudAccountUid.documentation: Finding cloud.account.uid, which is a unique identifier in the Amazon Web Services account..

FindingInfoUid.documentation: Finding finding_info.uid, which is a unique identifier for the finding from the finding provider.

MetadataProductUid.documentation: Finding metadata.product.uid, which is a unique identifier for the product.

OcsfFindingIdentifier.documentation: Provides a standard to identify security findings using OCSF.

OcsfMapFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of security findings based on map field values in OCSF.

OcsfNumberFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of security findings based on numerical field values in OCSF.

OcsfStringFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of security findings based on string field values in OCSF.

ConfigurationType.documentation:
Indicates whether the organization uses local or central configuration.

If you use local configuration, the Security Hub delegated administrator can set AutoEnable to true and AutoEnableStandards to DEFAULT. This automatically enables Security Hub and default security standards in new organization accounts. These new account settings must be set separately in each Amazon Web Services Region, and settings may be different in each Region.

If you use central configuration, the delegated administrator can create configuration policies. Configuration policies can be used to configure Security Hub, security standards, and security controls in multiple accounts and Regions. If you want new organization accounts to use a specific configuration, you can create a configuration policy and associate it with the root or specific organizational units (OUs). New accounts will inherit the policy from the root or their assigned OU.

Status.documentation: Describes whether central configuration could be enabled as the ConfigurationType for the organization. If your ConfigurationType is local configuration, then the value of Status is always ENABLED.

StatusMessage.documentation: Provides an explanation if the value of Status is equal to FAILED when ConfigurationType is equal to CENTRAL.

OrganizationConfiguration.documentation: Provides information about the way an organization is configured in Security Hub.

PageNumber.documentation: The page number of the page that contains the sensitive data.

LineRange.documentation: An occurrence of sensitive data detected in a non-binary text file or a Microsoft Word file. Non-binary text files include files such as HTML, XML, JSON, and TXT files.

OffsetRange.documentation: An occurrence of sensitive data detected in a binary text file.

Page.documentation: An occurrence of sensitive data in an Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) file.

ValueType.documentation:
Identifies whether a control parameter uses a custom user-defined value or subscribes to the default Security Hub behavior.

When ValueType is set equal to DEFAULT, the default behavior can be a specific Security Hub default value, or the default behavior can be to ignore a specific parameter. When ValueType is set equal to DEFAULT, Security Hub ignores user-provided input for the Value field.

When ValueType is set equal to CUSTOM, the Value field can't be empty.

Value.documentation: The current value of a control parameter.

ParameterConfiguration.documentation: An object that provides the current value of a security control parameter and identifies whether it has been customized.

ConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a control parameter. Customization options vary based on the data type of the parameter.

ParameterDefinition.documentation: An object that describes a security control parameter and the options for customizing it.

Integer.documentation: A control parameter that is an integer.

IntegerList.documentation: A control parameter that is a list of integers.

Double.documentation: A control parameter that is a double.

String.documentation: A control parameter that is a string.

StringList.documentation: A control parameter that is a list of strings.

Boolean.documentation: A control parameter that is a boolean.

Enum.documentation: A control parameter that is an enum.

EnumList.documentation: A control parameter that is a list of enums.

ParameterValue.documentation: An object that includes the data type of a security control parameter and its current value.

Id.documentation:
The identifier of the compliance standard that was used to determine the patch compliance status.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 256.

InstalledCount.documentation:
The number of patches from the compliance standard that were installed successfully.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

MissingCount.documentation:
The number of patches that are part of the compliance standard but are not installed. The count includes patches that failed to install.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

FailedCount.documentation:
The number of patches from the compliance standard that failed to install.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

InstalledOtherCount.documentation:
The number of installed patches that are not part of the compliance standard.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

InstalledRejectedCount.documentation:
The number of patches that are installed but are also on a list of patches that the customer rejected.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

InstalledPendingReboot.documentation:
The number of patches that were applied, but that require the instance to be rebooted in order to be marked as installed.

The value can be an integer from 0 to 100000.

OperationStartTime.documentation:
Indicates when the operation started.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

OperationEndTime.documentation:
Indicates when the operation completed.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

RebootOption.documentation:
The reboot option specified for the instance.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 256.

Operation.documentation:
The type of patch operation performed. For Patch Manager, the values are SCAN and INSTALL.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 256.

PatchSummary.documentation: Provides an overview of the patch compliance status for an instance against a selected compliance standard.

SecurityHub.documentation: The Amazon Web Services service that the configuration policy applies to.

Policy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If you provide a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If you provide a list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

PortProbeDetails.documentation: Information about the ports affected by the port probe.

Blocked.documentation: Indicates whether the port probe was blocked.

PortProbeAction.documentation: Provided if ActionType is PORT_PROBE. It provides details about the attempted port probe that was detected.

LocalPortDetails.documentation: Provides information about the port that was scanned.

LocalIpDetails.documentation: Provides information about the IP address where the scanned port is located.

RemoteIpDetails.documentation: Provides information about the remote IP address that performed the scan.

PortProbeDetail.documentation: A port scan that was part of the port probe. For each scan, PortProbeDetails provides information about the local IP address and port that were scanned, and the remote IP address that the scan originated from.

Begin.documentation: The first port in the port range.

End.documentation: The last port in the port range.

From.documentation: The first port in the port range.

To.documentation: The last port in the port range.

Name.documentation:
The name of the process.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1. Maximum of 64.

Path.documentation:
The path to the process executable.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1. Maximum of 512.

ParentPid.documentation: The parent process ID. This field accepts positive integers between O and 2147483647.

LaunchedAt.documentation:
Indicates when the process was launched.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

TerminatedAt.documentation:
Indicates when the process was terminated.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

ProcessDetails.documentation: The details of process-related information about a finding.

CompanyName.documentation: The name of the company that provides the product.

IntegrationTypes.documentation:
The types of integration that the product supports. Available values are the following.

  • SEND_FINDINGS_TO_SECURITY_HUB - The integration sends findings to Security Hub.

  • RECEIVE_FINDINGS_FROM_SECURITY_HUB - The integration receives findings from Security Hub.

  • UPDATE_FINDINGS_IN_SECURITY_HUB - The integration does not send new findings to Security Hub, but does make updates to the findings that it receives from Security Hub.

MarketplaceUrl.documentation:
For integrations with Amazon Web Services services, the Amazon Web Services Console URL from which to activate the service.

For integrations with third-party products, the Amazon Web Services Marketplace URL from which to subscribe to or purchase the product.

ActivationUrl.documentation: The URL to the service or product documentation about the integration with Security Hub, including how to activate the integration.

ProductSubscriptionResourcePolicy.documentation: The resource policy associated with the product.

CompanyName.documentation: The name of the organization or vendor that provides the productV2.

Categories.documentation: The domains or functional areas the productV2 addresses.

MarketplaceUrl.documentation: The console URL where you can purchase or subscribe to products.

ActivationUrl.documentation: The URL to the serviceV@ or productV2 documentation about the integration, which includes how to activate the integration.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

PropagatingVgwSetDetails.documentation: Describes a virtual private gateway propagating route.

JiraCloud.documentation: The configuration settings required to establish an integration with Jira Cloud.

ServiceNow.documentation: The configuration settings required to establish an integration with ServiceNow ITSM.

ProviderConfiguration.documentation: The initial configuration settings required to establish an integration between Security Hub and third-party provider.

ProviderDetail.documentation: The third-party provider detail for a service configuration.

JiraCloud.documentation: The parameters required to update the configuration for a Jira Cloud integration.

ProviderUpdateConfiguration.documentation: The parameters required to update the configuration of an integration provider.

Start.documentation: The number of lines (for a line range) or characters (for an offset range) from the beginning of the file to the end of the sensitive data.

End.documentation: The number of lines (for a line range) or characters (for an offset range) from the beginning of the file to the end of the sensitive data.

StartColumn.documentation: In the line where the sensitive data starts, the column within the line where the sensitive data starts.

Range.documentation: Identifies where the sensitive data begins and ends.

Text.documentation:
Describes the recommended steps to take to remediate an issue identified in a finding.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 512 length.

Url.documentation: A URL to a page or site that contains information about how to remediate a finding.

Recommendation.documentation: A recommendation on how to remediate the issue identified in a finding.

JsonPath.documentation: The path, as a JSONPath expression, to the field in the record that contains the data. If the field name is longer than 20 characters, it is truncated. If the path is longer than 250 characters, it is truncated.

RecordIndex.documentation: The record index, starting from 0, for the record that contains the data.

Record.documentation: An occurrence of sensitive data in an Apache Avro object container or an Apache Parquet file.

ProductArn.documentation: The ARN of the product that generated a related finding.

Id.documentation: The product-generated identifier for a related finding.

Recommendation.documentation: A recommendation on the steps to take to remediate the issue identified by a finding.

Remediation.documentation: Details about the remediation steps for a finding.

Type.documentation:
The type of the resource that details are provided for. If possible, set Type to one of the supported resource types. For example, if the resource is an EC2 instance, then set Type to AwsEc2Instance.

If the resource does not match any of the provided types, then set Type to Other.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 256.

Id.documentation: The canonical identifier for the given resource type.

Partition.documentation: The canonical Amazon Web Services partition name that the Region is assigned to.

Region.documentation:
The canonical Amazon Web Services external Region name where this resource is located.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 16.

ResourceRole.documentation: Identifies the role of the resource in the finding. A resource is either the actor or target of the finding activity,

Tags.documentation: A list of Amazon Web Services tags associated with a resource at the time the finding was processed. Tags must follow Amazon Web Services tag naming limits and requirements.

DataClassification.documentation: Contains information about sensitive data that was detected on the resource.

Details.documentation: Additional details about the resource related to a finding.

ApplicationName.documentation: The name of the application that is related to a finding.

ApplicationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the application that is related to a finding.

ResourceConflictException.documentation: The resource specified in the request conflicts with an existing resource.

AwsEc2Instance.documentation: Details about an EC2 instance related to a finding.

AwsEc2Subnet.documentation: Details about a subnet in Amazon EC2.

AwsEc2NetworkAcl.documentation: Details about an EC2 network access control list (ACL).

AwsS3Bucket.documentation: Details about an S3 bucket related to a finding.

AwsS3AccountPublicAccessBlock.documentation: Details about the Amazon S3 Public Access Block configuration for an account.

AwsS3Object.documentation: Details about an S3 object related to a finding.

AwsIamAccessKey.documentation: Details about an IAM access key related to a finding.

AwsApiGatewayV2Stage.documentation: Provides information about a version 2 stage for Amazon API Gateway.

AwsApiGatewayV2Api.documentation: Provides information about a version 2 API in Amazon API Gateway.

AwsApiGatewayStage.documentation: Provides information about a version 1 Amazon API Gateway stage.

AwsApiGatewayRestApi.documentation: Provides information about a REST API in version 1 of Amazon API Gateway.

AwsSsmPatchCompliance.documentation: Provides information about the state of a patch on an instance based on the patch baseline that was used to patch the instance.

AwsCertificateManagerCertificate.documentation: Provides details about an Certificate Manager certificate.

AwsRedshiftCluster.documentation: Contains details about an Amazon Redshift cluster.

AwsElbLoadBalancer.documentation: Contains details about a Classic Load Balancer.

AwsRdsDbInstance.documentation: Details about an Amazon RDS database instance.

AwsRdsDbSnapshot.documentation: Details about an Amazon RDS database snapshot.

AwsRdsDbClusterSnapshot.documentation: Details about an Amazon RDS database cluster snapshot.

AwsRdsDbCluster.documentation: Details about an Amazon RDS database cluster.

AwsEcsContainer.documentation: Provides information about a Docker container that's part of a task.

AwsEcsTaskDefinition.documentation: Details about a task definition. A task definition describes the container and volume definitions of an Amazon Elastic Container Service task.

Container.documentation: Details about a container resource related to a finding.

Other.documentation:
Details about a resource that are not available in a type-specific details object. Use the Other object in the following cases.

  • The type-specific object does not contain all of the fields that you want to populate. In this case, first use the type-specific object to populate those fields. Use the Other object to populate the fields that are missing from the type-specific object.

  • The resource type does not have a corresponding object. This includes resources for which the type is Other.

AwsRdsEventSubscription.documentation: Details about an RDS event notification subscription.

AwsEcsService.documentation: Details about a service within an ECS cluster.

AwsEc2VpnConnection.documentation: Details about an Amazon EC2 VPN connection.

AwsOpenSearchServiceDomain.documentation: Details about an Amazon OpenSearch Service domain.

AwsEc2VpcEndpointService.documentation: Details about the service configuration for a VPC endpoint service.

AwsXrayEncryptionConfig.documentation: Information about the encryption configuration for X-Ray.

AwsWafRateBasedRule.documentation: Details about a rate-based rule for global resources.

AwsWafRegionalRateBasedRule.documentation: Details about a rate-based rule for Regional resources.

AwsEcrRepository.documentation: Information about an Amazon Elastic Container Registry repository.

AwsNetworkFirewallFirewallPolicy.documentation: Details about an Network Firewall firewall policy.

AwsNetworkFirewallRuleGroup.documentation: Details about an Network Firewall rule group.

AwsRdsDbSecurityGroup.documentation: Details about an Amazon RDS DB security group.

AwsKinesisStream.documentation: Details about an Amazon Kinesis data stream.

AwsEc2TransitGateway.documentation: Details about an Amazon EC2 transit gateway that interconnects your virtual private clouds (VPC) and on-premises networks.

AwsEfsAccessPoint.documentation: Details about an Amazon EFS access point. An access point is an application-specific view into an EFS file system that applies an operating system user and group, and a file system path, to any file system request made through the access point.

AwsCloudFormationStack.documentation: Details about an CloudFormation stack. A stack is a collection of Amazon Web Services resources that you can manage as a single unit.

AwsCloudWatchAlarm.documentation: Details about an Amazon CloudWatch alarm. An alarm allows you to monitor and receive alerts about your Amazon Web Services resources and applications across multiple Regions.

AwsEc2VpcPeeringConnection.documentation: Details about an Amazon EC2 VPC peering connection. A VPC peering connection is a networking connection between two VPCs that enables you to route traffic between them privately.

AwsWafRegionalRuleGroup.documentation: Details about an WAF rule group for Regional resources.

AwsWafRegionalRule.documentation: Details about an WAF rule for Regional resources.

AwsWafRegionalWebAcl.documentation: Details about an WAF web access control list (web ACL) for Regional resources.

AwsWafRule.documentation: Details about an WAF rule for global resources.

AwsWafRuleGroup.documentation: Details about an WAF rule group for global resources.

AwsEcsTask.documentation: Details about a task in a cluster.

AwsBackupBackupVault.documentation: Provides details about an Backup backup vault.

AwsBackupBackupPlan.documentation: Provides details about an Backup backup plan.

AwsBackupRecoveryPoint.documentation: Provides details about an Backup backup, or recovery point.

AwsEc2RouteTable.documentation: Provides details about a route table. A route table contains a set of rules, called routes, that determine where to direct network traffic from your subnet or gateway.

AwsAmazonMqBroker.documentation: Provides details about AppSync message broker. A message broker allows software applications and components to communicate using various programming languages, operating systems, and formal messaging protocols.

AwsAppSyncGraphQlApi.documentation: Provides details about an AppSync Graph QL API, which lets you query multiple databases, microservices, and APIs from a single GraphQL endpoint.

AwsEventSchemasRegistry.documentation: A schema defines the structure of events that are sent to Amazon EventBridge. Schema registries are containers for schemas. They collect and organize schemas so that your schemas are in logical groups.

AwsGuardDutyDetector.documentation: Provides details about an Amazon GuardDuty detector. A detector is an object that represents the GuardDuty service. A detector is required for GuardDuty to become operational.

AwsStepFunctionStateMachine.documentation: Provides details about an Step Functions state machine, which is a workflow consisting of a series of event-driven steps.

AwsAthenaWorkGroup.documentation: Provides information about an Amazon Athena workgroup. A workgroup helps you separate users, teams, applications, or workloads. It also helps you set limits on data processing and track costs.

AwsEventsEventbus.documentation: Provides details about Amazon EventBridge event bus for an endpoint. An event bus is a router that receives events and delivers them to zero or more destinations, or targets.

AwsDmsEndpoint.documentation: Provides details about an Database Migration Service (DMS) endpoint. An endpoint provides connection, data store type, and location information about your data store.

AwsEventsEndpoint.documentation: Provides details about an Amazon EventBridge global endpoint. The endpoint can improve your application’s availability by making it Regional-fault tolerant.

AwsDmsReplicationTask.documentation: Provides details about an DMS replication task. A replication task moves a set of data from the source endpoint to the target endpoint.

AwsDmsReplicationInstance.documentation: Provides details about an DMS replication instance. DMS uses a replication instance to connect to your source data store, read the source data, and format the data for consumption by the target data store.

AwsRoute53HostedZone.documentation: Provides details about an Amazon Route 53 hosted zone, including the four name servers assigned to the hosted zone. A hosted zone represents a collection of records that can be managed together, belonging to a single parent domain name.

AwsMskCluster.documentation: Provides details about an Amazon Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (Amazon MSK) cluster.

AwsS3AccessPoint.documentation: Provides details about an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) access point. S3 access points are named network endpoints that are attached to S3 buckets that you can use to perform S3 object operations.

AwsEc2ClientVpnEndpoint.documentation: Provides details about an Client VPN endpoint. A Client VPN endpoint is the resource that you create and configure to enable and manage client VPN sessions. It's the termination point for all client VPN sessions.

CodeRepository.documentation: Details about an external code repository with which you can connect your Amazon Web Services resources. The connection is established through Amazon Inspector.

ResourceDetails.documentation:
Additional details about a resource related to a finding.

To provide the details, use the object that corresponds to the resource type. For example, if the resource type is AwsEc2Instance, then you use the AwsEc2Instance object to provide the details.

If the type-specific object does not contain all of the fields you want to populate, then you use the Other object to populate those additional fields.

You also use the Other object to populate the details when the selected type does not have a corresponding object.

FindingType.documentation: The category or classification of the security finding.

ProductName.documentation: The name of the product associated with the security finding.

Severities.documentation: A breakdown of security findings by their severity levels.

ResourceFindingsSummary.documentation: A list of summaries for all finding types on a resource.

GroupByField.documentation: Specifies the attribute that resources should be grouped by.

Filters.documentation: The criteria used to select resources and associated security findings.

ResourceGroupByRule.documentation: Defines the configuration for organizing and categorizing Amazon Web Services resources based on associated security findings.

ResourceInUseException.documentation: The request was rejected because it conflicts with the resource's availability. For example, you tried to update a security control that's currently in the UPDATING state.

ResourceNotFoundException.documentation: The request was rejected because we can't find the specified resource.

ResourceArn.documentation: Specifies the ARN that uniquely identifies a resource.

AccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account that owns the resource.

Region.documentation: The Amazon Web Services Region where the resource is located.

ResourceCreationTimeDt.documentation: The time when the resource was created.

ResourceDetailCaptureTimeDt.documentation: The timestamp when information about the resource was captured.

FindingsSummary.documentation: An aggregated view of security findings associated with a resource.

ResourceTags.documentation: The key-value pairs associated with a resource.

ResourceResult.documentation: Provides comprehensive details about an Amazon Web Services resource and its associated security findings.

Other.documentation: The number of findings not in any of the severity categories.

Fatal.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level of fatal.

Critical.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level of critical.

High.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level of high.

Medium.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level of medium.

Low.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level of low.

Informational.documentation: The number of findings that provide security-related information.

Unknown.documentation: The number of findings with a severity level cannot be determined.

ResourceSeverityBreakdown.documentation: A comprehensive distribution of security findings by severity level for Amazon Web Services resources.

Key.documentation: The identifier or name of the tag.

Value.documentation: The data associated with the tag key.

ResourceTag.documentation: Represents tag information associated with Amazon Web Services resources.

StringFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on string field values.

DateFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on date and timestamp field values.

NumberFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on numerical field values.

MapFilters.documentation: Enables filtering based on map-based field values.

Operator.documentation: The logical operator used to combine multiple filter conditions.

ResourcesCompositeFilter.documentation: Enables the creation of criteria for Amazon Web Services resources in Security Hub.

ResourcesDateFilter.documentation: Enables the filtering of Amazon Web Services resources based on date and timestamp attributes.

CompositeFilters.documentation: A collection of complex filtering conditions that can be applied to Amazon Web Services resources.

CompositeOperator.documentation: The logical operator used to combine multiple filter conditions in the structure.

ResourcesFilters.documentation: Enables filtering of Amazon Web Services resources based on data.

ResourcesMapFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of Amazon Web Services resources based on key-value map attributes.

ResourcesNumberFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of Amazon Web Services resources based on numerical values.

ResourcesStringFilter.documentation: Enables filtering of Amazon Web Services resources based on string field values.

AccountId.documentation: An Amazon Web Services account ID of the account that was not processed.

ProcessingResult.documentation: The reason that the account was not processed.

Result.documentation: Details about the account that was not processed.

CarrierGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the carrier gateway.

CoreNetworkArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the core network.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The IPv4 CIDR block used for the destination match.

DestinationIpv6CidrBlock.documentation: The IPv6 CIDR block used for the destination match.

DestinationPrefixListId.documentation: The prefix of the destination Amazon Web Services service.

EgressOnlyInternetGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the egress-only internet gateway.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of a gateway attached to your VPC.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

InstanceOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the instance.

LocalGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the local gateway.

NatGatewayId.documentation: The ID of a NAT gateway.

NetworkInterfaceId.documentation: The ID of the network interface.

Origin.documentation: Describes how the route was created.

TransitGatewayId.documentation: The ID of a transit gateway.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of a VPC peering connection.

RouteSetDetails.documentation: Provides details about the routes in the route table.

RuleVariables.documentation: Additional settings to use in the specified rules.

RulesSource.documentation:
The rules and actions for the rule group.

For stateful rule groups, can contain RulesString, RulesSourceList, or StatefulRules.

For stateless rule groups, contains StatelessRulesAndCustomActions.

RulesSourceList.documentation: Stateful inspection criteria for a domain list rule group. A domain list rule group determines access by specific protocols to specific domains.

RulesString.documentation: Stateful inspection criteria, provided in Suricata compatible intrusion prevention system (IPS) rules.

StatelessRulesAndCustomActions.documentation: The stateless rules and custom actions used by a stateless rule group.

RuleGroupSource.documentation: The rules and actions for the rule group.

ActionName.documentation: A descriptive name of the custom action.

RuleGroupSourceCustomActionsDetails.documentation: A custom action definition. A custom action is an optional, non-standard action to use for stateless packet handling.

GeneratedRulesType.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny access to the domains listed in Targets.

TargetTypes.documentation: The protocols that you want to inspect. Specify LS_SNI for HTTPS. Specify HTTP_HOST for HTTP. You can specify either or both.

Targets.documentation: The domains that you want to inspect for in your traffic flows. You can provide full domain names, or use the '.' prefix as a wildcard. For example, .example.com matches all domains that end with example.com.

RuleGroupSourceListDetails.documentation: Stateful inspection criteria for a domain list rule group.

Action.documentation: Defines what Network Firewall should do with the packets in a traffic flow when the flow matches the stateful rule criteria.

Header.documentation: The stateful inspection criteria for the rule.

Destination.documentation: The destination IP address or address range to inspect for, in CIDR notation. To match with any address, specify ANY.

DestinationPort.documentation: The destination port to inspect for. You can specify an individual port, such as 1994. You also can specify a port range, such as 1990:1994. To match with any port, specify ANY.

Direction.documentation: The direction of traffic flow to inspect. If set to ANY, the inspection matches bidirectional traffic, both from the source to the destination and from the destination to the source. If set to FORWARD, the inspection only matches traffic going from the source to the destination.

Protocol.documentation: The protocol to inspect for. To inspector for all protocols, use IP.

Source.documentation: The source IP address or address range to inspect for, in CIDR notation. To match with any address, specify ANY.

SourcePort.documentation: The source port to inspect for. You can specify an individual port, such as 1994. You also can specify a port range, such as 1990:1994. To match with any port, specify ANY.

RuleGroupSourceStatefulRulesHeaderDetail.documentation: The inspection criteria for a stateful rule.

RuleGroupSourceStatefulRulesOptionsDetai.documentation: A rule option for a stateful rule.

Actions.documentation: The actions to take on a packet that matches one of the stateless rule definition's match attributes. You must specify a standard action (aws:pass, aws:drop, or aws:forward_to_sfe). You can then add custom actions.

MatchAttributes.documentation: The criteria for Network Firewall to use to inspect an individual packet in a stateless rule inspection.

DestinationPorts.documentation: A list of port ranges to specify the destination ports to inspect for.

Destinations.documentation: The destination IP addresses and address ranges to inspect for, in CIDR notation.

SourcePorts.documentation: A list of port ranges to specify the source ports to inspect for.

Sources.documentation: The source IP addresses and address ranges to inspect for, in CIDR notation.

TcpFlags.documentation: The TCP flags and masks to inspect for.

FromPort.documentation: The starting port value for the port range.

ToPort.documentation: The ending port value for the port range.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRuleMatchAttribu.documentation: A port range to specify the destination ports to inspect for.

AddressDefinition.documentation: An IP address or a block of IP addresses.

FromPort.documentation: The starting port value for the port range.

ToPort.documentation: The ending port value for the port range.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRuleMatchAttribu.documentation: A port range to specify the source ports to inspect for.

AddressDefinition.documentation: An IP address or a block of IP addresses.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRuleMatchAttribu.documentation: A source IP addresses and address range to inspect for.

Flags.documentation: Defines the flags from the Masks setting that must be set in order for the packet to match. Flags that are listed must be set. Flags that are not listed must not be set.

Masks.documentation: The set of flags to consider in the inspection. If not specified, then all flags are inspected.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRuleMatchAttribu.documentation: A set of TCP flags and masks to inspect for.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRulesAndCustomAc.documentation: Stateless rules and custom actions for a stateless rule group.

Priority.documentation: Indicates the order in which to run this rule relative to all of the rules in the stateless rule group.

RuleDefinition.documentation: Provides the definition of the stateless rule.

RuleGroupSourceStatelessRulesDetails.documentation: A stateless rule in the rule group.

IpSets.documentation: A list of IP addresses and address ranges, in CIDR notation.

RuleGroupVariables.documentation: Additional settings to use in the specified rules.

Definition.documentation: The list of IP addresses and ranges.

RuleGroupVariablesIpSetsDetails.documentation: A list of IP addresses and address ranges, in CIDR notation.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The unique identifier of a security control across standards. Values for this field typically consist of an Amazon Web Services service name and a number, such as APIGateway.3.

SecurityControlArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for a security control across standards, such as arn:aws:securityhub:eu-central-1:123456789012:security-control/S3.1. This parameter doesn't mention a specific standard.

Description.documentation: The description of a security control across standards. This typically summarizes how Security Hub evaluates the control and the conditions under which it produces a failed finding. This parameter doesn't reference a specific standard.

RemediationUrl.documentation: A link to Security Hub documentation that explains how to remediate a failed finding for a security control.

SeverityRating.documentation: The severity of a security control. For more information about how Security Hub determines control severity, see Assigning severity to control findings in the Security Hub User Guide.

SecurityControlStatus.documentation: The enablement status of a security control in a specific standard.

UpdateStatus.documentation: Identifies whether customizable properties of a security control are reflected in Security Hub findings. A status of READY indicates that Security Hub uses the current control parameter values when running security checks of the control. A status of UPDATING indicates that all security checks might not use the current parameter values.

Parameters.documentation: An object that identifies the name of a control parameter, its current value, and whether it has been customized.

LastUpdateReason.documentation: The most recent reason for updating the customizable properties of a security control. This differs from the UpdateReason field of the BatchUpdateStandardsControlAssociations API, which tracks the reason for updating the enablement status of a control. This field accepts alphanumeric characters in addition to white spaces, dashes, and underscores.

SecurityControl.documentation: A security control in Security Hub describes a security best practice related to a specific resource.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The ID of the security control.

Parameters.documentation: An object that specifies parameter values for a control in a configuration policy.

SecurityControlCustomParameter.documentation: A list of security controls and control parameter values that are included in a configuration policy.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The unique identifier of a security control across standards. Values for this field typically consist of an Amazon Web Services service name and a number (for example, APIGateway.3). This parameter differs from SecurityControlArn, which is a unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) assigned to a control. The ARN references the security control ID (for example, arn:aws:securityhub:eu-central-1:123456789012:security-control/APIGateway.3).

Title.documentation: The title of a security control.

Description.documentation: The description of a security control across standards. This typically summarizes how Security Hub evaluates the control and the conditions under which it produces a failed finding. This parameter doesn't reference a specific standard.

RemediationUrl.documentation: A link to Security Hub documentation that explains how to remediate a failed finding for a security control.

SeverityRating.documentation: The severity of a security control. For more information about how Security Hub determines control severity, see Assigning severity to control findings in the Security Hub User Guide.

CurrentRegionAvailability.documentation: Specifies whether a security control is available in the current Amazon Web Services Region.

CustomizableProperties.documentation: Security control properties that you can customize. Currently, only parameter customization is supported for select controls. An empty array is returned for controls that don’t support custom properties.

ParameterDefinitions.documentation: An object that provides a security control parameter name, description, and the options for customizing it. This object is excluded for a control that doesn't support custom parameters.

SecurityControlDefinition.documentation: Provides metadata for a security control, including its unique standard-agnostic identifier, title, description, severity, availability in Amazon Web Services Regions, and a link to remediation steps.

Name.documentation: The name of a

Value.documentation: The current value of a control parameter.

SecurityControlParameter.documentation: A parameter that a security control accepts.

EnabledSecurityControlIdentifiers.documentation: A list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy. Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls) other than the listed controls.

DisabledSecurityControlIdentifiers.documentation: A list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy. Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls) other than the listed controls.

SecurityControlCustomParameters.documentation: A list of security controls and control parameter values that are included in a configuration policy.

SecurityControlsConfiguration.documentation: An object that defines which security controls are enabled in an Security Hub configuration policy. The enablement status of a control is aligned across all of the enabled standards in an account.

ServiceEnabled.documentation: Indicates whether Security Hub is enabled in the policy.

EnabledStandardIdentifiers.documentation: A list that defines which security standards are enabled in the configuration policy.

SecurityControlsConfiguration.documentation: An object that defines which security controls are enabled in the configuration policy. The enablement status of a control is aligned across all of the enabled standards in an account.

SecurityHubPolicy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. The configuration policy includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If you provide a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If you provide a list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

Count.documentation: The total number of occurrences of sensitive data that were detected.

Type.documentation: The type of sensitive data that was detected. For example, the type might indicate that the data is an email address.

Occurrences.documentation: Details about the sensitive data that was detected.

SensitiveDataDetections.documentation: The list of detected instances of sensitive data.

Category.documentation: The category of sensitive data that was detected. For example, the category can indicate that the sensitive data involved credentials, financial information, or personal information.

Detections.documentation: The list of detected instances of sensitive data.

TotalCount.documentation: The total number of occurrences of sensitive data.

SensitiveDataResult.documentation: Contains a detected instance of sensitive data that are based on built-in identifiers.

Uid.documentation: Unique identifier of the attack sequence.

Actors.documentation: Provides information about the actors involved in the attack sequence.

Endpoints.documentation: Contains information about the network endpoints that were used in the attack sequence.

Signals.documentation: Contains information about the signals involved in the attack sequence.

SequenceIndicators.documentation: Contains information about the indicators observed in the attack sequence. The values for SignalIndicators are a subset of the values for SequenceIndicators, but the values for these fields don't always match 1:1.

Sequence.documentation: Contains information about an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence finding. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events align to a potentially suspicious activity. To receive GuardDuty attack sequence findings in Security Hub, you must have GuardDuty enabled. For more information, see GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

AuthStatus.documentation: The status of the authorization between Jira Cloud and the service.

ServiceNowProviderConfiguration.documentation: The initial configuration settings required to establish an integration between Security Hub and ServiceNow ITSM.

Product.documentation:
Deprecated. This attribute isn't included in findings. Instead of providing Product, provide Original.

The native severity as defined by the Amazon Web Services service or integrated partner product that generated the finding.

Label.documentation:
The severity value of the finding. The allowed values are the following.

  • INFORMATIONAL - No issue was found.

  • LOW - The issue does not require action on its own.

  • MEDIUM - The issue must be addressed but not urgently.

  • HIGH - The issue must be addressed as a priority.

  • CRITICAL - The issue must be remediated immediately to avoid it escalating.

If you provide Normalized and don't provide Label, then Label is set automatically as follows.

  • 0 - INFORMATIONAL

  • 1–39 - LOW

  • 40–69 - MEDIUM

  • 70–89 - HIGH

  • 90–100 - CRITICAL

Normalized.documentation:
Deprecated. The normalized severity of a finding. Instead of providing Normalized, provide Label.

The value of Normalized can be an integer between 0 and 100.

If you provide Label and don't provide Normalized, then Normalized is set automatically as follows.

  • INFORMATIONAL - 0

  • LOW - 1

  • MEDIUM - 40

  • HIGH - 70

  • CRITICAL - 90

Original.documentation:
The native severity from the finding product that generated the finding.

Length Constraints: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 64.

Severity.documentation:
The severity of the finding.

The finding provider can provide the initial severity. The finding provider can only update the severity if it hasn't been updated using BatchUpdateFindings.

The finding must have either Label or Normalized populated. If only one of these attributes is populated, then Security Hub automatically populates the other one. If neither attribute is populated, then the finding is invalid. Label is the preferred attribute.

Normalized.documentation:
The normalized severity for the finding. This attribute is to be deprecated in favor of Label.

If you provide Normalized and don't provide Label, Label is set automatically as follows.

  • 0 - INFORMATIONAL

  • 1–39 - LOW

  • 40–69 - MEDIUM

  • 70–89 - HIGH

  • 90–100 - CRITICAL

Product.documentation: The native severity as defined by the Amazon Web Services service or integrated partner product that generated the finding.

Label.documentation:
The severity value of the finding. The allowed values are the following.

  • INFORMATIONAL - No issue was found.

  • LOW - The issue does not require action on its own.

  • MEDIUM - The issue must be addressed but not urgently.

  • HIGH - The issue must be addressed as a priority.

  • CRITICAL - The issue must be remediated immediately to avoid it escalating.

SeverityUpdate.documentation: Updates to the severity information for a finding.

Type.documentation:
The type of the signal used to identify an attack sequence.

Signals can be GuardDuty findings or activities observed in data sources that GuardDuty monitors. For more information, see GuardDuty foundational data sources in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

A signal type can be one of the following values. Here are the related descriptions:

  • FINDING - Individually generated GuardDuty finding.

  • CLOUD_TRAIL - Activity observed from CloudTrail logs

  • S3_DATA_EVENTS - Activity observed from CloudTrail data events for Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3). Activities associated with this type will show up only when you have enabled GuardDuty S3 Protection feature in your account. For more information about S3 Protection and the steps to enable it, see S3 Protection in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

Id.documentation: The identifier of the signal.

Title.documentation: The description of the GuardDuty finding.

ProductArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the product that generated the signal.

ResourceIds.documentation: The ARN or ID of the Amazon Web Services resource associated with the signal.

SignalIndicators.documentation: Contains information about the indicators associated with the signals in this attack sequence finding. The values for SignalIndicators are a subset of the values for SequenceIndicators, but the values for these fields don't always match 1:1.

Name.documentation: The name of the GuardDuty signal. For example, when signal type is FINDING, the signal name is the name of the finding.

CreatedAt.documentation: The timestamp when the first finding or activity related to this signal was observed.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp when this signal was last observed.

FirstSeenAt.documentation: The timestamp when the first finding or activity related to this signal was observed.

LastSeenAt.documentation: The timestamp when the last finding or activity related to this signal was observed.

Severity.documentation: The severity associated with the signal. For more information about severity, see Severity levels for GuardDuty findings in the Amazon GuardDuty User Guide.

Count.documentation: The number of times this signal was observed.

ActorIds.documentation: The IDs of the threat actors involved in the signal.

EndpointIds.documentation: Information about the endpoint IDs associated with this signal.

Signal.documentation:
Contains information about the signals involved in an Amazon GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection attack sequence. An attack sequence is a type of threat detected by GuardDuty. GuardDuty generates an attack sequence finding when multiple events, or signals, align to a potentially suspicious activity. When GuardDuty and Security Hub are integrated, GuardDuty sends attack sequence findings to Security Hub.

A signal can be an API activity or a finding that GuardDuty uses to detect an attack sequence finding.

Name.documentation: The name of the software package.

Architecture.documentation: The architecture used for the software package.

FilePath.documentation: The file system path to the package manager inventory file.

FixedInVersion.documentation: The version of the software package in which the vulnerability has been resolved.

Remediation.documentation: Describes the actions a customer can take to resolve the vulnerability in the software package.

SourceLayerHash.documentation: The source layer hash of the vulnerable package.

SourceLayerArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the source layer.

Field.documentation: The finding attribute used to sort findings.

SortCriterion.documentation: A collection of finding attributes used to sort findings.

Name.documentation: The name of the standard.

EnabledByDefault.documentation:
Whether the standard is enabled by default. When Security Hub is enabled from the console, if a standard is enabled by default, the check box for that standard is selected by default.

When Security Hub is enabled using the EnableSecurityHub API operation, the standard is enabled by default unless EnableDefaultStandards is set to false.

StandardsManagedBy.documentation: Provides details about the management of a standard.

Standard.documentation: Provides information about a specific security standard.

StandardsControlArn.documentation: The ARN of the security standard control.

ControlStatus.documentation: The current status of the security standard control. Indicates whether the control is enabled or disabled. Security Hub does not check against disabled controls.

DisabledReason.documentation: The reason provided for the most recent change in status for the control.

ControlStatusUpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the status of the security standard control was most recently updated.

ControlId.documentation: The identifier of the security standard control.

Title.documentation: The title of the security standard control.

Description.documentation: The longer description of the security standard control. Provides information about what the control is checking for.

RemediationUrl.documentation: A link to remediation information for the control in the Security Hub user documentation.

SeverityRating.documentation:
The severity of findings generated from this security standard control.

The finding severity is based on an assessment of how easy it would be to compromise Amazon Web Services resources if the issue is detected.

RelatedRequirements.documentation: The list of requirements that are related to this control.

StandardsControl.documentation: Details for an individual security standard control.

StandardsArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a security standard.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The unique identifier of a security control across standards. Values for this field typically consist of an Amazon Web Services service name and a number, such as APIGateway.3.

SecurityControlArn.documentation: The ARN of a security control across standards, such as arn:aws:securityhub:eu-central-1:123456789012:security-control/S3.1. This parameter doesn't mention a specific standard.

AssociationStatus.documentation: Specifies whether a control is enabled or disabled in a specified standard.

RelatedRequirements.documentation: The requirement that underlies a control in the compliance framework related to the standard.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The time at which the enablement status of the control in the specified standard was last updated.

UpdatedReason.documentation: The reason for updating the enablement status of a control in a specified standard.

StandardsControlTitle.documentation: The title of a control. This field may reference a specific standard.

StandardsControlDescription.documentation: The description of a control. This typically summarizes how Security Hub evaluates the control and the conditions under which it produces a failed finding. This parameter may reference a specific standard.

StandardsControlArns.documentation: Provides the input parameter that Security Hub uses to call the UpdateStandardsControl API. This API can be used to enable or disable a control in a specified standard.

StandardsControlAssociationDetail.documentation: Provides details about a control's enablement status in a specified standard.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The unique identifier (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) of a security control across standards.

StandardsControlAssociationId.documentation: An array with one or more objects that includes a security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) and the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a standard. The security control ID or ARN is the same across standards.

StandardsArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a standard.

SecurityControlId.documentation: A unique standard-agnostic identifier for a control. Values for this field typically consist of an Amazon Web Services service and a number, such as APIGateway.5. This field doesn't reference a specific standard.

SecurityControlArn.documentation: The ARN of a control, such as arn:aws:securityhub:eu-central-1:123456789012:security-control/S3.1. This parameter doesn't mention a specific standard.

AssociationStatus.documentation: The enablement status of a control in a specific standard.

RelatedRequirements.documentation: The requirement that underlies this control in the compliance framework related to the standard.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The last time that a control's enablement status in a specified standard was updated.

UpdatedReason.documentation: The reason for updating a control's enablement status in a specified standard.

StandardsControlDescription.documentation: The description of a control. This typically summarizes how Security Hub evaluates the control and the conditions under which it produces a failed finding. The parameter may reference a specific standard.

StandardsControlAssociationSummary.documentation: An array that provides the enablement status and other details for each control that applies to each enabled standard.

StandardsArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the standard in which you want to update the control's enablement status.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The unique identifier for the security control whose enablement status you want to update.

AssociationStatus.documentation: The desired enablement status of the control in the standard.

UpdatedReason.documentation: The reason for updating the control's enablement status in the standard.

StandardsControlAssociationUpdate.documentation: An array of requested updates to the enablement status of controls in specified standards. The objects in the array include a security control ID, the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the standard, the requested enablement status, and the reason for updating the enablement status.

Company.documentation: An identifier for the company that manages a specific security standard. For existing standards, the value is equal to Amazon Web Services.

Product.documentation: An identifier for the product that manages a specific security standard. For existing standards, the value is equal to the Amazon Web Services service that manages the standard.

StandardsManagedBy.documentation: Provides details about the management of a security standard.

StatusReasonCode.documentation: The reason code that represents the reason for the current status of a standard subscription.

StandardsStatusReason.documentation: The reason for the current status of your subscription to the standard.

StandardsSubscriptionArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource that represents your subscription to the standard.

StandardsInput.documentation: A key-value pair of input for the standard.

StandardsStatus.documentation:
The status of your subscription to the standard. Possible values are:

  • PENDING - The standard is in the process of being enabled. Or the standard is already enabled and Security Hub is adding new controls to the standard.

  • READY - The standard is enabled.

  • INCOMPLETE - The standard could not be enabled completely. One or more errors (StandardsStatusReason) occurred when Security Hub attempted to enable the standard.

  • DELETING - The standard is in the process of being disabled.

  • FAILED - The standard could not be disabled. One or more errors (StandardsStatusReason) occurred when Security Hub attempted to disable the standard.

StandardsControlsUpdatable.documentation:
Specifies whether you can retrieve information about and configure individual controls that apply to the standard. Possible values are:

  • READY_FOR_UPDATES - Controls in the standard can be retrieved and configured.

  • NOT_READY_FOR_UPDATES - Controls in the standard cannot be retrieved or configured.

StandardsSubscription.documentation: A resource that represents your subscription to a supported standard.

StandardsArn.documentation: The ARN of the standard that you want to enable. To view the list of available standards and their ARNs, use the DescribeStandards operation.

StandardsInput.documentation: A key-value pair of input for the standard.

StandardsSubscriptionRequest.documentation: The standard that you want to enable.

ConfigurationPolicyIdentifier.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a configuration policy, the universally unique identifier (UUID) of a configuration policy, or a value of SELF_MANAGED_SECURITY_HUB for a self-managed configuration.

Target.documentation: The identifier of the target account, organizational unit, or the root to associate with the specified configuration.

ConfigurationPolicyId.documentation: The UUID of the configuration policy.

TargetId.documentation: The identifier of the target account, organizational unit, or the organization root with which the configuration is associated.

TargetType.documentation: Indicates whether the target is an Amazon Web Services account, organizational unit, or the organization root.

AssociationType.documentation: Indicates whether the association between the specified target and the configuration was directly applied by the Security Hub delegated administrator or inherited from a parent.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy association was last updated.

AssociationStatus.documentation: The current status of the association between the specified target and the configuration.

AssociationStatusMessage.documentation: An explanation for a FAILED value for AssociationStatus.

Target.documentation: The identifier of the target account, organizational unit, or the root to disassociate from the specified configuration.

ConfigurationPolicyIdentifier.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a configuration policy, the universally unique identifier (UUID) of a configuration policy, or a value of SELF_MANAGED_SECURITY_HUB for a self-managed configuration.

PublishMetricAction.documentation: Information about metrics to publish to CloudWatch.

StatelessCustomActionDefinition.documentation: The definition of a custom action that can be used for stateless packet handling.

StatelessCustomPublishMetricAction.documentation: Information about metrics to publish to CloudWatch.

Value.documentation: The value to use for the custom metric dimension.

StatelessCustomPublishMetricActionDimens.documentation: Defines a CloudWatch dimension value to publish.

ReasonCode.documentation: A code that represents a reason for the control status. For the list of status reason codes and their meanings, see Compliance details for control findings in the Security Hub User Guide.

Description.documentation: The corresponding description for the status reason code.

StatusReason.documentation: Provides additional context for the value of Compliance.Status.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a control parameter that is a string.

Re2Expression.documentation: An RE2 regular expression that Security Hub uses to validate a user-provided control parameter string.

ExpressionDescription.documentation: The description of the RE2 regular expression.

StringConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a string.

Value.documentation: The string filter value. Filter values are case sensitive. For example, the product name for control-based findings is Security Hub. If you provide security hub as the filter value, there's no match.

Comparison.documentation:
The condition to apply to a string value when filtering Security Hub findings.

To search for values that have the filter value, use one of the following comparison operators:

  • To search for values that include the filter value, use CONTAINS. For example, the filter Title CONTAINS CloudFront matches findings that have a Title that includes the string CloudFront.

  • To search for values that exactly match the filter value, use EQUALS. For example, the filter AwsAccountId EQUALS 123456789012 only matches findings that have an account ID of 123456789012.

  • To search for values that start with the filter value, use PREFIX. For example, the filter ResourceRegion PREFIX us matches findings that have a ResourceRegion that starts with us. A ResourceRegion that starts with a different value, such as af, ap, or ca, doesn't match.

CONTAINS, EQUALS, and PREFIX filters on the same field are joined by OR. A finding matches if it matches any one of those filters. For example, the filters Title CONTAINS CloudFront OR Title CONTAINS CloudWatch match a finding that includes either CloudFront, CloudWatch, or both strings in the title.

To search for values that don’t have the filter value, use one of the following comparison operators:

  • To search for values that exclude the filter value, use NOT_CONTAINS. For example, the filter Title NOT_CONTAINS CloudFront matches findings that have a Title that excludes the string CloudFront.

  • To search for values other than the filter value, use NOT_EQUALS. For example, the filter AwsAccountId NOT_EQUALS 123456789012 only matches findings that have an account ID other than 123456789012.

  • To search for values that don't start with the filter value, use PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS. For example, the filter ResourceRegion PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS us matches findings with a ResourceRegion that starts with a value other than us.

NOT_CONTAINS, NOT_EQUALS, and PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS filters on the same field are joined by AND. A finding matches only if it matches all of those filters. For example, the filters Title NOT_CONTAINS CloudFront AND Title NOT_CONTAINS CloudWatch match a finding that excludes both CloudFront and CloudWatch in the title.

You can’t have both a CONTAINS filter and a NOT_CONTAINS filter on the same field. Similarly, you can't provide both an EQUALS filter and a NOT_EQUALS or PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS filter on the same field. Combining filters in this way returns an error. CONTAINS filters can only be used with other CONTAINS filters. NOT_CONTAINS filters can only be used with other NOT_CONTAINS filters.

You can combine PREFIX filters with NOT_EQUALS or PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS filters for the same field. Security Hub first processes the PREFIX filters, and then the NOT_EQUALS or PREFIX_NOT_EQUALS filters.

For example, for the following filters, Security Hub first identifies findings that have resource types that start with either AwsIam or AwsEc2. It then excludes findings that have a resource type of AwsIamPolicy and findings that have a resource type of AwsEc2NetworkInterface.

  • ResourceType PREFIX AwsIam

  • ResourceType PREFIX AwsEc2

  • ResourceType NOT_EQUALS AwsIamPolicy

  • ResourceType NOT_EQUALS AwsEc2NetworkInterface

CONTAINS and NOT_CONTAINS operators can be used only with automation rules V1. CONTAINS_WORD operator is only supported in GetFindingsV2, GetFindingStatisticsV2, GetResourcesV2, and GetResourceStatisticsV2 APIs. For more information, see Automation rules in the Security Hub User Guide.

StringFilter.documentation: A string filter for filtering Security Hub findings.

DefaultValue.documentation: The Security Hub default value for a control parameter that is a list of strings.

Re2Expression.documentation: An RE2 regular expression that Security Hub uses to validate a user-provided list of strings for a control parameter.

MaxItems.documentation: The maximum number of list items that a string list control parameter can accept.

ExpressionDescription.documentation: The description of the RE2 regular expression.

StringListConfigurationOptions.documentation: The options for customizing a security control parameter that is a list of strings.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource to apply the tags to.

Tags.documentation: The tags to add to the resource. You can add up to 50 tags at a time. The tag keys can be no longer than 128 characters. The tag values can be no longer than 256 characters.

AccountId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the target account.

OrganizationalUnitId.documentation: The organizational unit ID of the target organizational unit.

RootId.documentation: The ID of the organization root.

Target.documentation: The target account, organizational unit, or the root that is associated with an Security Hub configuration. The configuration can be a configuration policy or self-managed behavior.

Name.documentation:
The name of the threat.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

Severity.documentation:
The severity of the threat.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 128 length.

ItemCount.documentation: This total number of items in which the threat has been detected.

FilePaths.documentation:
Provides information about the file paths that were affected by the threat.

Array Members: Minimum number of 1 item. Maximum number of 5 items.

Threat.documentation: Provides information about the threat detected in a security finding and the file paths that were affected by the threat.

Type.documentation: The type of threat intelligence indicator.

Value.documentation:
The value of a threat intelligence indicator.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 512 length.

Category.documentation: The category of a threat intelligence indicator.

LastObservedAt.documentation:
Indicates when the most recent instance of a threat intelligence indicator was observed.

For more information about the validation and formatting of timestamp fields in Security Hub, see Timestamps.

Source.documentation:
The source of the threat intelligence indicator.

Length Constraints: Minimum of 1 length. Maximum of 64 length.

SourceUrl.documentation: The URL to the page or site where you can get more information about the threat intelligence indicator.

ThreatIntelIndicator.documentation: Details about the threat intelligence related to a finding.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The limit on the number of requests per second was exceeded.

RuleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the unprocessed automation rule.

ErrorCode.documentation: The error code associated with the unprocessed automation rule.

ErrorMessage.documentation: An error message describing why a request didn't process a specific rule.

UnprocessedAutomationRule.documentation: A list of objects containing RuleArn, ErrorCode, and ErrorMessage. This parameter tells you which automation rules the request didn't process and why.

ConfigurationPolicyAssociationIdentifier.documentation: Configuration policy association identifiers that were specified in a BatchGetConfigurationPolicyAssociations request but couldn’t be processed due to an error.

ErrorCode.documentation: An HTTP status code that identifies why the configuration policy association failed.

ErrorReason.documentation: A string that identifies why the configuration policy association failed.

UnprocessedConfigurationPolicyAssociatio.documentation: An array of configuration policy associations, one for each configuration policy association identifier, that was specified in a BatchGetConfigurationPolicyAssociations request but couldn’t be processed due to an error.

SecurityControlId.documentation: The control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) for which a response couldn't be returned.

ErrorCode.documentation: The error code for the unprocessed security control.

ErrorReason.documentation: The reason why the security control was unprocessed.

UnprocessedSecurityControl.documentation: Provides details about a security control for which a response couldn't be returned.

StandardsControlAssociationId.documentation: An array with one or more objects that includes a security control (identified with SecurityControlId, SecurityControlArn, or a mix of both parameters) and the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a standard. This parameter shows the specific controls for which the enablement status couldn't be retrieved in specified standards when calling BatchUpdateStandardsControlAssociations.

ErrorCode.documentation: The error code for the unprocessed standard and control association.

ErrorReason.documentation: The reason why the standard and control association was unprocessed.

UnprocessedStandardsControlAssociation.documentation: Provides details about which control's enablement status couldn't be retrieved in a specified standard when calling BatchUpdateStandardsControlAssociations. This parameter also provides details about why the request was unprocessed.

StandardsControlAssociationUpdate.documentation: An array of control and standard associations for which an update failed when calling BatchUpdateStandardsControlAssociations.

ErrorCode.documentation: The error code for the unprocessed update of the control's enablement status in the specified standard.

ErrorReason.documentation: The reason why a control's enablement status in the specified standard couldn't be updated.

UnprocessedStandardsControlAssociationUp.documentation: Provides details about which control's enablement status could not be updated in a specified standard when calling the BatchUpdateStandardsControlAssociations API. This parameter also provides details about why the request was unprocessed.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource to remove the tags from.

TagKeys.documentation: The tag keys associated with the tags to remove from the resource. You can remove up to 50 tags at a time.

ActionTargetArn.documentation: The ARN of the custom action target to update.

Name.documentation: The updated name of the custom action target.

Description.documentation: The updated description for the custom action target.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Determines how Amazon Web Services Regions should be linked to the Aggregator V2.

LinkedRegions.documentation: A list of Amazon Web Services Regions linked to the aggegation Region.

AggregationRegion.documentation: The Amazon Web Services Region where data is aggregated.

RegionLinkingMode.documentation: Determines how Amazon Web Services Regions should be linked to the Aggregator V2.

LinkedRegions.documentation: A list of Amazon Web Services Regions linked to the aggegation Region.

RuleOrder.documentation: Represents a value for the rule priority.

Criteria.documentation: The filtering type and configuration of the automation rule.

Actions.documentation: A list of actions to be performed when the rule criteria is met.

RuleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the rule.

RuleStatus.documentation: Whether the rule is active after it is created. If this parameter is equal to ENABLED, Security Hub starts applying the rule to findings and finding updates after the rule is created. To change the value of this parameter after creating a rule, use BatchUpdateAutomationRules .

RuleOrder.documentation: An integer ranging from 1 to 1000 that represents the order in which the rule action is applied to findings. Security Hub applies rules with lower values for this parameter first.

IsTerminal.documentation: Specifies whether a rule is the last to be applied with respect to a finding that matches the rule criteria. This is useful when a finding matches the criteria for multiple rules, and each rule has different actions. If a rule is terminal, Security Hub applies the rule action to a finding that matches the rule criteria and doesn't evaluate other rules for the finding. By default, a rule isn't terminal.

Criteria.documentation: A set of ASFF finding field attributes and corresponding expected values that Security Hub uses to filter findings. If a rule is enabled and a finding matches the conditions specified in this parameter, Security Hub applies the rule action to the finding.

Actions.documentation: One or more actions to update finding fields if a finding matches the conditions specified in Criteria.

UpdateAutomationRulesRequestItem.documentation: Specifies the parameters to update in an existing automation rule.

Identifier.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) or universally unique identifier (UUID) of the configuration policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy. Alphanumeric characters and the following ASCII characters are permitted: -, ., !, *, /.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

UpdatedReason.documentation: The reason for updating the configuration policy.

ConfigurationPolicy.documentation:
An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If you provide a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls). If you provide a list of security controls that are disabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub enables all other controls (including newly released controls).

When updating a configuration policy, provide a complete list of standards that you want to enable and a complete list of controls that you want to enable or disable. The updated configuration replaces the current configuration.

Arn.documentation: The ARN of the configuration policy.

Id.documentation: The UUID of the configuration policy.

Name.documentation: The name of the configuration policy.

Description.documentation: The description of the configuration policy.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was last updated.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time, in UTC and ISO 8601 format, that the configuration policy was created.

ConfigurationPolicy.documentation: An object that defines how Security Hub is configured. It includes whether Security Hub is enabled or disabled, a list of enabled security standards, a list of enabled or disabled security controls, and a list of custom parameter values for specified controls. If the request included a list of security controls that are enabled in the configuration policy, Security Hub disables all other controls (including newly released controls).
